loans.name: Laumua

texts.en:
Laumua F. is 46 and married with 5 children.  She owns a business venture, selling a variety of different products in the local community.  Laumua has 3 years of experience in this business.  Laumua needs a loan of WST $1750 to purchase additional products to sell.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 800 talas or US $333 per week) to improve/expand the business.

Laumua joined SPBD.  This is her 4th loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Laumua's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Laumua F. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.6 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.5 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.7 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2.3 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

loans.name: Uk

texts.en: Mr. Uk P., 41, is married to Sek Trop, 40, and they have five children. One of them is married and the others are single. His wife stays at home to raise a few pigs to generate a small income for the family. Uk P. has been learning the skill of building wooden houses since he was single and he has been using his knowledge to earn a living. Additionally, the family takes time to farm rice when the farming season comes. To earn more income, Uk P. is taking his first loan to buy fertilizers and rice seeds to better grow his crop.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and rice seeds to better grow his crop

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en:
Sonia B. is a 28-year-old woman who is passionate about her desire for having her own children. It has been one year and a half since she married her husband who is a farmer. Since then, they both long to have their own children. Despite not having one until now, Sonia believes that since her and her husband’s faith is strong, one day God will answer their prayer.  

Instead of preoccupying herself with the thought of having her own child to nurture and love, she concentrates on loving and caring for her husband instead. She saw how hard he works all day in the field just to have his own income to provide her with her needs. Thus, she wanted to help him enhance his rice farming business by supporting his financial need to be able to purchase fertilizer, seedlings and other necessary farm inputs. Since her membership in ASHI in 2009, some portion of the loans she received has been used for this purpose and some was used to put up her own business which is a “sari-sari” (variety) store business.  

Sonia feels happy having her own business to manage, because she can be productive and make herself her busy and not think too much about having a baby. Now, she is requesting a larger amount to finance her intention of growing her “sari-sari” store. She wants to have more savings to be able to improve their standard of living while they don’t have children yet and in preparation for having children in the future.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items for her "sari-sari" store

loans.name: Chorng

texts.en:
Mrs. Chorng N., 27, has had a small business selling a few items to neighbors in the village. She is able to generate US$ 3 or $4 a day from selling cooking ingredients, ice cream, and some fruit. She also relies on the income from her husband who operates a motor-taxi service around the community. 

Chorng N. is blessed with a young child who is enrolled in school and also depends on her. Chorng N. will be using her money to rent farmland where cashews are grown. She will harvest and sell cashews when they are ripe. This will provide her with extra income.

loans.use: To rent farmland where cashews are grown

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace D. V. is from the village of Canituan, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 33 years old. Grace is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Grace owns & operates a business venture in the food sector, butchering and selling meat in the market. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from butchering & selling pork in the market. Grace has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Grace joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Grace has successfully repaid a previous loan of 11,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Grace is requesting a new loan of 14,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 4th loan taken out by Grace from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: Lumbia, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Basharaf Group

texts.en:
M. M., son of M. K., 35 years old, is the group leader of 'Basharaf' Group. He lives in Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married and he sells credit cards for mobile phones. When he started this business for the first time, he had a small business and he was very weak in running the business, but when he got an individual loan he really improved a lot in his business and still he is furthering his business, attracting good numbers of customers, making a good income for his family, and repaying the loan without any difficulty and on time. 

M. M. is happy with this loan. He would like to thank both Kiva and AFS (Ariana Financial Serves Joint Stock Company) and all lenders around the world who help workers and people who would like to expand their businesses. Finally, he wants to say that this process is a successful one in Afghanistan.

loans.use: expanding his mobile phone credit business

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane E. is from the village of San Carlos, Tukuran Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 38 years old. Mary Jane is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Mary Jane owns & operates a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as sugar, candies, biscuits, shampoo, soap & toothpaste in the local community. Mary Jane has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Mary Jane joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Mary Jane has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Mary Jane is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Mary Jane from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ing

texts.en:
Ing C., age 54, is widowed and resides with one of her children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia. She is engaged in a business of selling various kinds of desserts at her home, earning approximately USD 3 in revenue per day. She has been in this business since 2002. She also rents part of her house to workers at the garment factory in front of her house.  Her son helps his mother in the business and is a civil servant, earning an income of USD 3 per day. 

Their standard of living has improved since they have had these businesses, so they want to have a loan to expand their businesses. C. is requesting a loan of 500 USD to repair her rental rooms for the workers. This is her second loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva. (C. is pictured with her son and his family.)

loans.use: repair the rental rooms for the workers

loans.name: Sisifo

texts.en:
Sisifo F. is 37 and married with 4 children (ages -month - 14).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting cocoa for sale.  Sisifo has 3 years of experience in this business.  Sisifo needs a loan of WST $2200 to purchase general farm supplies & equipment.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to pay for her children's tuition fees.

In 2007, Sisifo joined SPBD.  This is her 3rd loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Sisifo's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Sisifo F. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.4 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.3 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.3 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              1.4 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

loans.name: Hem

texts.en:
Hem S., aged 59, is widowed and lives with her two children in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia. She sells various kinds of Cambodian traditional medicines, and earns approximately $3 USD in revenue per day. She has been running this business since 1990. Both her children are employed in a local garment factory, earning an income of $4 USD each per day. The family's standard of living has improved since they have engaged in these businesses.
Hem S. is requesting a loan of $800 USD to purchase a plot of farmland to grow more rice in the dry season. This is her second loan from Kiva partner, CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland to grow rice

loans.name: Toch

texts.en:
Mr. Toch T. is 55 years old and lives in Kompong Tom, a province of Cambodia, located about 200 km from Phnom Penh.
Toch T. owns and uses a motorcycle to pick up passengers around his community for a profit. In addition, his wife (who appears in the photo here) produces cakes and sells them to people in the village. The couple has six children, half of whom are now married and the rest of whom are single. Besides their current work, the family takes time to plant rice crops. Toch T. also has an ox that he uses to provide a breeding service for a fee. Toch T. has seen that this service is very profitable, so he would like to request a loan to buy more oxen to provide this service.

loans.use: To buy more oxen to provide a breeding service

loans.name: Voang

texts.en:
Voang C., aged 43, is widowed and resides with her husband in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia. She has four children. 
Voang C. works in the agricultural sector growing rice, and earns approximately $4 USD in revenue per day. She has been engaged in this business since 2004. Two of her children are employed in a local garment factory, earning an income of $3 USD each per day. 
The family's standard of living has improved since C. started her business, so she is requesting a loan of $1,200 USD to expand it by purchasing a machine to grind rice. By doing so, she will be able to use the machine to grind her rice product from the field, and make more money by renting out the machine. This is Voang C.'s third loan from Kiva partner, CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy a machine to grind rice

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
Emma P. is from the village of Militar, Tukuran Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 45 years old. Emma is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Emma owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling candies, some food for snacks, shampoo and etc. in the local community. Emma has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Emma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Emma is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Emma from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

texts.en: Mr. Ses P. was born in 1975 and is currently a resident of Kompong Tom province, where he earns a living selling wood carvings. His wife, who appears in the photo here, is a vegetable grower in the village. The family lives with two kids who are attending the public local school. Ses P. has an older house that is surrounded by pollution, affecting his health and his daily living conditions. To resolve the problem, Ses P. requested a loan to buy a plot of land to cover the bad conditions.

loans.use: To buy a plot of land to cover the bad conditions.

loans.name: Talaileva

texts.en:
Talaileva S. is 49 and married with 6 children (ages 2 - 10).  She owns a business venture, selling pancakes (fried flour pancakes flavored with lemon or coconut jam).  Talaileva has 2 years of experience in this business.  Talaileva needs a loan of WST $1500 to buy flour, flavoring, sugar, and plastic bags.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Talaileva joined SPBD.    This is her 2nd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Talaileva's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.name: Oun

texts.en: Oun S. is married and resides with her husband in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia. She has a young child. She is engaged in a business of selling river shells at a local market in her town, earning an income of USD 4.76 per day to help cover her family expenses. Her husband is a construction worker, earning an income of USD 3.56 per day. Their standard of living has been improved since they have had these businesses. S. is requesting a loan of 500 USD to purchase a new motorbike for her husband. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.name: Zilpha

texts.en:
Zilpha D. is from the village of Dela Paz, Pana-on, Misamis Occidental. She is 56 years old. Zilpha is married and has seven adult children. To make a living, Zilpha owns & operates a specialized retail store selling daily use products such as canned goods, soap, cigarettes, shampoo & toothpaste in the local community. Zilpha has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Zilpha joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zilpha has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Zilpha is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Zilpha from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Rosenda

texts.en:
Rosenda S. is from the village of Dawo. She is 47 years old, single, and has a school-aged child. To make a living, she runs a general store  selling a variety of different products. Rosenda has been in the business for over seven years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month. 

In 2008, Rosenda joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Rosenda is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her inventory. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Rosenda from PMPC and the second from KIVA. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.name: Tsetsenbal

texts.en: Tsetsenbal is 36 years old and lives with her three children in a ger, the traditional Mongolian tent, in Arhangai province, Mongolia. Her parents live with them and help support Tsetsenbal and her business. During the day, she operates a trading business selling second-hand products such as shoes, clothing, and blankets. Previously, she had operated a food trading business which she started in 2003 with a working capital of 150,000 tugrugs (~ 105 USD). She has been working with Xacbank since 2004, and is a reliable client. Tsetsenbal is a very hard-working and open-minded person. The most important thing for her is her children's education. She says: “I am working hard to be financially able to pay for my children's education.” Tsetsenbal is requesting a 150,000 tugrug (~ 105 USD) loan to purchase second-hand shoes to resell for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase secondhand shoes and resell them

loans.name: Tatupu

texts.en:
"Tatupu M. is 53 and married with 4 children (ages 17 - 28).  She owns a business venture, selling puletasi (Samoan formal wear).  Tatupu has many years of experience in this business.  Tatupu needs a loan of WST $2000 to purchase additional fabrics & materials.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 450 talas or US $188 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2008, Tatupu joined SPBD.  This is her 4th loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Tatupu's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Tatupu M. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.5 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.5 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.5 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase additional fabrics & materials

loans.name: Altangerel

texts.en: Altangerel is 55 years old and lives with his wife in Arhangai, Mongolia. They live in a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent called a ger. Their children are grown and have left home. Altangerel and his wife operate a dairy production business at a local market. He produces and sells milk, curd and skim milk. He has been in the business since 2007 and has steadily expanded it. During the summer he sells only milk but in the spring and autumn he sells other dairy products as well. Altangerel would like to improve his livestock and develop breeds. He is optimistic about the future and hopes to grow his business into a stable operation. Altangerel is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug (~ 2815 USD) loan to purchase livestock.

loans.use: To purchase livestock for his diary business

loans.name: Metuli

texts.en:
Metuli Maliota is 55 and married with 5 children (ages 15 - 29).  She is starting a business venture,  which is flower garden.  Metuli needs a loan of WST $1000 to purchse additional garden equipments.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 450 talas or US $188 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Metuli joined SPBD.    This is her 1st loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Metuli's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Metuli Maliota are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.6 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.5 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         1.5 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              2.5 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase additional  garden equipments

loans.name: Faalilo

texts.en:
Faalilo S. is 63 and married with 5 children (ages 15 - 36).  She owns a business venture, selling food products in the local community.  Faalilo has 2 years of experience in this business.  Faalilo needs a loan of WST $1500 to purchase additional products to sell.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 550 talas or US $229 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2009, Faalilo joined SPBD.    This is her 2nd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Faalilo's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Agustina

texts.en:
Agustina A. is a 57-year-old married woman who lives in Hda. San Ramon, Brgy. Poblacion, Bayawan City, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by fruit vending. Agustina’s husband Fortunato, who is 70 years old, has a hog-raising business. Because they have no children, they are saving up their earnings so that they can support themselves in their old age.

Agustina joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve their quality of life. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in fruit vending. Now she earns an average monthly income of Php 18,000 from her business activities.

Agustina is a member in good standing. In her previous loan cycle, she only borrowed Php 3,000 to augment her working capital for her fruit vending business,  but now that summer is here and fruit is abundant, she is borrowing (for her 14th loan) the amount of Php 15,000, which she intends to use to buy more stock for her fruit vending business. Agustina is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family--to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital for the business

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma L., 45 years old, is a married woman who supports her family by engaging in vegetable vending in the local market. She lives in Brgy 5, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental with her husband Marino and their 9 children, 4 of whom are already working, 4 are students, and one is still a baby.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her vegetable vending business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 6,500.

Vilma is now borrowing Php 17,000 so that she could buy more stocks for her vegetable vending business. This will be her 9th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Vilma aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Aurelia

texts.en:
Aurelia M. is a 55-year-old married woman who lives in Brgy. Prosperidad, San Carlos City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by running a general store and a restaurant/eatery. Aurelia’s husband Dio who is 60 years old helps his wife in running the business. They have 3 children who are between 25 to 40 years old, two of whom have their own families; one is still single but is already gainfully employed.

Aurelia joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2003 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by running her general store and restaurant/eatery business. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP 22,400 from her business activities.

Aurelia is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of Php 20,000 was used to fund operations of her general store and restaurant, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing for her 13th loan, the amount of Php 20,000, which she intends to use to sustain the operations of her general store.  Aurelia is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Lubukumu Nakiwala Mwamini Group

texts.en: N. Mwamini is a hardworking businesswoman, 33 years old and married with three children. One of her children is in school. She carries out a tailoring service, which she has been operating for over three years. She is using the loan to add capital into her business to purchase material to make designs for her customers. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to obtain land and construct a house.

loans.use: To purchase more material to make designs for her customers.

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Carmelita T. is a 48-year-old widow who supports her family by running a general store and restaurant or eatery business. She lives in Brgy. Prosperidad, San Carlos City, Negros Occidental with her two married children (who are 23 and 24 years old) and her two grandchildren.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and restaurant businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 19,600.

Carmelita is now borrowing PHP 17,000 so that she could continue to sustain her general store and restaurant. This will be her 13th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 15,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Carmelita aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: As additional working capital

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is a 59-year-old woman who heads a family of six people of whom three are her children aged 27, 25 and 6 years. Her major dream for her family is education for her children.

Betty has a retail shop in Masindi, Uganda which she has operated for the last eight years. She sells home consumables and drinks in her shop with the help of her son when he is not at school.

This is Betty’s third loan from HOFOKAM Limited. The purpose of the loan is to pay school fees for her children so that they can study at school without being sent home for non-payment of school fees.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her children

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia is a 55-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating a general store and a photography business. She lives in Brgy. Tapi Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental with her husband, Israel, who is a photographer and their two children. The children are 20 & 23 years old and still go to school.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and photography business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 28,000.

Alicia is now borrowing PHP 17,000 so that she can sustain her general store. This will be her 18th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 19,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Alicia aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: As additional working capital

loans.name: Shamshad's Group

texts.en:
Shamshad is the wife of M. R. and lives in a city called Borewala, in Pakistan. Borewala city is famous for its shrines. Her husband is an electrician but also sells electrical supplies in the community. He has been in this trade for the past 15 years. Shamshad has given birth to five children: three sons and two daughters. Her elder daughter helps her with household work. The eldest son goes with his father and helps him in his electric shop. The others don’t do anything.

Shamshad is applying for a loan to buy electrical supplies (wires, switches, and tube lights) to expand her husbands’ electrical supply-selling business. She has two other ladies in her loan group. Rafiqan and Mumtaz each want a loan to buy donkey carts for their loading businesses.

loans.use: To buy electrical supplies to sell

loans.name: Long

texts.en: Mrs. Long O. is a 43-year-old married mother who resides in a commune located in Kompong Tom province. Here she established a small family home in 1995. To seek a daily profit, Long O. breeds a few pigs in a pigpen next to her house. Additionally she goes to the forest with her husband to carve firewood to sell for extra income. To earn additional income, Long O. needs a loan for capital to accumulate more pigs to raise. Long O. has four children: two are employed and other two are students.

loans.use: To accumulate more pigs to raise.

loans.name: Rashidan's Group

texts.en:
Rashidan is a seamstress, living in a city called Borewala, a city famous for its shrines in Pakistan. She sews clothes for women specifically and earns approximately Pak Rs. 5,000. Her earning allows her to pay the utilities. 

Her husband's name is M. N. and he is a driver by profession and drives a rented auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). At the end of the day he pays half the money to the owner. His earning doesn’t cover the day-to-day expenses of his family. Therefore they have decided to apply for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) so that he gets the full money earned through his struggle and can meet the expenses.

Rashidan has three other ladies in her loan group. Amina wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits & vegetables to resell. Zainab wants a loan to buy construction supplies (cement & bricks) for her construction supply-selling business. Sharifan wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Nakigalala South Najjemba Bena Group

texts.en: N. Bena is a hardworking business who is 21 years old. She is married with two children, of whom one is schooling. She has a stone quarrying business and she has been operating this business for over two years. She is using the loan for her stone quarrying business. The business is improving as well as the family. Her future plan is to get more money and build a house.

loans.use: For her stone quarrying business.

loans.name: Yem

texts.en: Yem S. is married and resides with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She has three children. She is engaged in the business of selling various kinds of groceries at home. She also buys vegetables from local farmers in her province for resale and she plants bananas on her own plot of farmland, earning an income of USD 10 per day to help cover her family expenses. Her husband is a driver for his brother’s car, earning an income of USD 4.10 per day. Their standard of living has improved since they have had these businesses. S. is requesting a loan of 1,200 USD to buy bananas for sale when the price is good. She also wants to dig a well. This is her second loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: To buy bananas and dig a well

loans.name: Sourn

texts.en: Sourn S. is married and resides with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She has two children. She is engaged in growing rice on her own plot of farmland, earning an income of USD 0.6 per day to help cover her family expenses. Her husband operates a business refilling gas for lighters and earns an income of USD 3.3 per day. The standard of living has been improved since they have had these businesses. S. is requesting a loan of 500 USD to purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute easily for his current business. This is her first loan from CREDIT, partnered with Kiva.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Maqsoodan's Group

texts.en:
Maqsoodan has been a citizen of a city called Borewala, in Pakistan for the past 25 years. Borewala city is famous for its shrines. She is a 40-year-old woman and continuously devotes herself to a sewing business. Her clientele base lives in her community. She receives orders and returns them on time. She is an expert in making designer and non-designer clothes. She does this work to meet the family's expenses together with her husband. Her husband's name is M. S. and he is a loader, transporting items  such as cement and bricks on his donkey cart. He has fifteen years of experience in this business. Currently, his cart has become broken down and rotted in different areas. Therefore, Maqsoodan is applying for a loan to buy a new donkey cart for her husband so he can better perform his duties. 

Maqsoodan has two other ladies in her loan group. Sakina and Muniran each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shops.

loans.use: To buy a new donkey cart

loans.name: Kim

texts.en:
Kim T. is married and resides with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She has four children.

Kim is engaged in a business selling bananas, earning an income of 1.50 USD per day to help cover her family expenses. Her husband operates his horse and cart to provide transportation services for the villagers, earning an income of 2 USD per day.

Their standard of living has been improved since they have had these businesses. T. is requesting a loan of 800 USD to buy bananas to stock for sale when the price is good. This is her second loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy bananas to stock for sale

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth, aged 48 years, is the mother of eight. She operates a bar from which she sustains the welfare of the four of her children she lives with. She lives in a rented house in Masindi, Uganda, which accommodates her family and the business.

Ruth has been in the bar business for ten years now. She says she started selling small quantities of alcohol but has seen her bar grow over the years with the help of the profits made and credit facilities from HOFOKAM.

Ruth will use the loan funds to pay tuition fees for her daughter, Jacinta, who is at college.

loans.use: To pay tuition fees for her daughter

loans.name: Khet

texts.en:
Khet S. is married and resides with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She has a fifteen-year-old child.

S. is engaged in growing rice on her own plot of farmland, earning an income of USD 1 per day to help cover her family expenses. Her husband buys bananas from the local farmers to stock for sale, earning a gross income of USD 13.30 per day. Their standard of living has been improved since they have had these businesses.

S. is requesting a loan of 900 USD to buy bananas to stock for sale when the price is good. This is her second loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy more bananas for her husband's business

loans.name: Nasreen Akhtar's Group

texts.en:
Bushra parveen wants a loan to buy seasonal fruit for her fruit-selling business. Kaniz wants a loan to buy a buffalo for her milk-selling business. Kalsoom wants a loan to buy a new donkey cart for loading. Yasmeen wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Nasreen akhtar is the group leader for the  above-mentioned ladies. They all live in Borewala, a city famous for its shrines in Pakistan.

Nasreen operates a cloth-selling business. Once a month she travels to various cities (Lahore & Multan) and purchases the cloth. She receives orders from her community. Her income allows her to meet the family's expenses, together with her husband. 

Her husband's name is M. H. and he is a loader by trade. He used a donkey cart for his loading business. He transports items such as construction supplies and delivers them to the required places. His work gives him Pak Rs. 8,000 every month. Now he is facing a problem: his cart has become rough and rotted in different areas which creates a hurdle in his work. So Nasreen is applying for a loan of worth Pak Rs. 20,000 to buy a new donkey cart for her husband so he can better do his business.

loans.use: To buy a new donkey cart

loans.name: Ngourn

texts.en:
Ngourn M. is married and lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She has three children.

M. is engaged in growing bananas on her own plot of farmland, earning an income of 2.50 USD per day to help cover her family expenses. Her husband operates his horse and cart in the village to provide transportation services and buys bananas for resale, earning an income of 4.80 USD per day. Their standard of living has been improved since they have had these businesses.

M. is requesting a loan of 1,000 USD to buy bananas to stock for sale when the price is good. This is her second loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy bananas to stock for sale

loans.name: Khouth

texts.en:
The person appearing in the photo is Mrs. P., 45, who lives in Kompong Tom Province, Cambodia, where she owns a medium-sized kiosk for selling groceries. In addition, she goes to buy fish in bulk to retail in the market. Her husband helps feed the family by investing in a haircutting trade. The couple has been married for many years but have no child yet.

Recently, P. sold all the grocery inventory from her store and she wants to buy more items to continue selling. Because she doesn’t have money, she decided to request a loan to be used to purchase more grocery items for her kiosk.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery items for her kiosk

loans.name: Ken

texts.en:
Ken N. is married and resides with her husband (shown in the photo) in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. She has two children. She stays at home as a housewife and takes care of the household chores.

Her husband is a skillful painter, earning an income of USD 10 per day. He has been in this business since 2001. Their standard of living has been improved since he has had this business.

N. is requesting a loan of 1,000 USD to buy a motorbike to easily transport her husband’s paintings to his middlemen. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to transport her husband's paintings

loans.name: Ramula

texts.en:
Ramula is 35 years old and is married to a driver. She has three children aged 17, 15 and 10 years. Both she and her husband contribute to the family welfare.

Ramula is a fishmonger operating in the central market in Masindi, Uganda. She has been a fishmonger for fifteen years and now hopes to become a large-scale supplier of fish.

Ramula got to know about HOFOKAM through friends who advised her to seek credit to bridge the finance gap in her business and in the family welfare. This is her second loan from HOFOKAM and she will use the funds to pay school fees for her two sons in high school.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her two sons in high school

loans.name: El

texts.en:
El S. is married and resides with his wife (shown in the photo) in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. He has three children.

S. operates his motorbike as a driver everywhere in the city, earning an income of 3 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. His wife sells fruits and fried bananas at home, earning an income of 3 USD per day. She has been with this business since 2005. Their standard of living has been improved since they have had these businesses.

S. is requesting a loan of 600 USD to buy more fruit to stock his wife’s store. This is his fifth loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy more fruit for his wife to sell

loans.name: Noeline

texts.en:
Noeline is the 29-year-old mother of three children aged 10, 6 and 2 years. She is married to an engineer and both of them contribute to the family welfare. She lives in a family of six people and she dreams of a good residential home for her family as her family’s goal.

Noeline is employed at a petrol (gasoline) station as a pump attendant but she also owns a clothing shop in Masindi, Uganda, which has been in operation for ten years now. This is her third loan from HOFOKAM and she will use it to purchase more clothes and shoes to sell.

loans.use: To purchasing more clothes and shoes to sell

loans.name: Ley

texts.en: Mrs. Ley N.  is married with a young child who is enrolled in primary school. She currently stays at home to care for the child and raise a few pigs to earn a living. Her husband (shown in the photo) is skilled in decorating wooden objects by hand. He produces beds, armchairs, windows and other furniture ordered by his customers. He faces a difficulty sending his finish products to his customers because he does not have a vehicle for transportation. He has discussed this with his wife and they have decided to request a loan of $700 USD to buy a motorcycle to connect with an existing trailer so that they can transport the furniture.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle to connect with existing trailer for transporting furniture

loans.name: Darlison

texts.en:
Darlison, shown with her son, is the 49-year-old single mother of two children aged five and three years. She lives in a family of six people.

Darlison is an administrator of Rock Foundation School in Masindi, Uganda. Her family goal is to bring up disciplined, God-fearing children and to see them through their education.

This is Darlison’s first loan from HOFOKAM and she intends to use it to improve her residential home with better furniture and fittings.

loans.use: To improve her home with better furniture and fittings

loans.name: Sam

texts.en:
Sam N. is widowed and lives with her two children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. Since 2005, she has had a business selling various kinds of fruits and also providing a money exchange service. She earns an income of $5 USD per day to help cover family expenses. The family is also assisted by one of her children who sells dry fish at a local market in the city. The family's standard of living has improved since they have had these businesses. N. is requesting a loan of $1,000 USD to buy more dry fish for resale. This is her third loan from Kiva partner, CREDIT.
The photograph shows Sam N.'s daughter with her dry fish stand at the market.

loans.use: To buy dry fish for resale

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Chea S., aged 46, is married and lives with his wife in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. He has four children. S. is a soldier in the city, earning an income of $5 USD per day to help cover family expenses. His wife sells groceries and runs a food shop at her home, earning an income of $7 USD per day. She has been running this business since 2005. The family's standard of living has been improved since S.'s wife has had this business. S. is requesting a loan of $300 USD to buy more groceries to stock his wife's store. This is his fifth loan from Kiva partner, CREDIT.
The photograph shows S.'s wife.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock his wife's store

loans.name: Chhuch

texts.en:
Mr. S., 44, has been a Khmer primary teacher since 1980. He has a life partner in his wife who sells a small amount of grocery and some sweets in front of their home. The couple has a young child who attends school. S. has saved up many sets of housing tools in order to build a new house, but construction is never started because he always lacks some essential tool. S. is therefore looking for a loan to buy more housing materials so he can start building his new house. 
Note: S. was not available at the time of the photograph, so his wife is pictured at their house instead.

loans.use: To buy tools to build a new house

loans.name: Ros

texts.en:
Ros M. is married and resides with her children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. She has six children.

M. is engaged in a business producing sacks (usually of strong material), earning an income of 2 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. The family is also assisted by her husband who is a construction worker, earning an income of 10 USD per day. He has been with his business since 2000. Their standard of living has been improved since they have had these businesses.

M. is requesting a loan of 1,000 USD to build rental rooms for garment factory workers. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To build rental rooms for workers at the factory

loans.name: Posiano

texts.en:
T. Posiano is an enterprising farmer in Rukungiri. He is a married man with seven children and his future plans are centered on developing his banana plantation.

Challenges like a lack of capital to expand his banana gardens, banana wilt disease, and finding the money to pay his odd jobbing casual laborers, are what Posiano has had to come to grips with ever since he began his business of growing and selling bananas nine years ago. His determination, though, has kept him going and, for that reason, he is now looking at the wider horizon.

In essence, Posiano’s future plans are to expand his business and educate all his children to university level. By his own account, a loan to the tune of 0.5 million UGX will lend support to his growth plans and ambitions. He hopes to buy more manure, mulch his plantations and buy stalk poles for better yields.

loans.use: To buy more manure, mulch and poles for his banana plantation

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda, 43, widens her rice field by removing the grasses in her land and continues planting. Using her rice-farming business, she would like to send her children to school. She has six children and the eldest is 23 years old.

In August 2008, Yolanda joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and now she has requested a loan to support her business. She asked for 14,000 Php to buy fertilizer and insecticide to have an abundant harvest.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and insecticide for her rice field

loans.name: Kong

texts.en:
Kong T. is married and lives with her children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. She has three children.

T. is engaged in the business of sewing and designing clothes and rents part of her house to garment factory workers, earning an income of 7 USD per day to help cover the family expenses. The family is also assisted by her husband who is a bodyguard at a public department, earning an income of 5 USD per day. Their standard of living has been improved since they have had these businesses.

T. is requesting a loan of 1,000 USD to repair the rental rooms for the workers. This is her first loan from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To repair her rental rooms

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
33-year old Evelyn tills a rice field in Bunawan, Agusan Del Sur. Rice farming is the only way she can provide the needs of her family. She needs additional capital to run her rice-farming business since she lacks seed and fertilizer. 

Community Economic Ventures, Inc. gives Evelyn an opportunity to obtain a loan to fulfill the needs for her farm. She requested a loan of 14,000 Php which will be helpful to buy supplies to produce a good harvest in the future.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer and other farm inputs

loans.name: Ngourn

texts.en: Ngourn C. T. lives with his wife in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. He has a business as a phone seller and repairman, earning an income of USD 18 per day. His wife helps with the business which they have had since 2008 and which has improved their standard of living. T. is requesting a loan of  $1,000 to buy a computer and phone repair equipment to expand his business. This is his first loan from CREDIT, in partnership with Kiva.

loans.use: buy a computer and phone repair equipment

loans.name: Letecia

texts.en: Letecia owns a one-hectare field in Bunawan, Agusan Del Sur where she farms rice. She needs additional capital to buy fertilizers, pesticides, and seeds. She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. and asks for a loan of 14,000 Php which will help her a lot in her business.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizer and pesticide

loans.name: Chorn

texts.en: Chorn S. lives with his five children in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. He is a construction foreman who works all over the city, earning an income of $8 per day to help cover family expenses. He has been in this business since 1983 which has improved his standard of living. S. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to buy construction equipment. This is his first loan from CREDIT, partnered Kiva.

loans.use: buy construction equipment

loans.name: Saron

texts.en:
Mrs. Saron T. is a villager in Roteang village in the Kandal province. She was born in 1952. She and her husband, Mr. Chhieng Orieng, are farmers who own a small piece of land and grow and sell vegetables to support their family. 

This family has some problems with the vegetable field, including infertile soil and a lot of insects. Thus, Mrs. Saron T. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer, pesticide and vegetable seeds for growing. 

She is a mother of four children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory, one is a construction worker, while the other is a farmer. Her husband is on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticide and vegetable seeds

loans.name: Mary Jean

texts.en: Mary Jean, at the young age of 18, cultivates a rice field to earn a living. She needs more farm materials to run her rice-farming business in Bunawan, Agusan Del Sur. As a member of Community Economic Ventures, Inc., she asked for a loan of 11,000 Philippine pesos. This will be enough help to provide the supplies for her rice field.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Rwakahurwa Group, Rukungiri

texts.en:
B. Peninah, is shown in the small photo and she also appears in the big group photo. She is the leader of her lending group in Rukungiri. She is 42 years old and a widow with five children, with only one in vocational training while the others finished secondary level.

Peninah has been involved in poultry farming in Rwakahurwa village for over two years and one of her biggest challenges is the lack of funds to restock more birds and buy more feed. She keeps the chickens for local consumption and she is able to make 63,000/= as weekly profits.

Peninah has a dream of breeding more birds for commercial farming as well as having a family that is respected in the village. She needs a loan to be able to buy more feed for her farm.

loans.use: To buy more feed for her chickens

loans.name: Rosalinda's Group

texts.en:
Rosalinda T. is from the village of Gomez San Isidro. She is 40 years old. Rosalinda is the group leader of a six-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Rosalinda T..

Rosalinda is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalinda owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Rosalinda has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rosalinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalinda is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rosalinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Vong

texts.en:
Mrs. Vong Y. is a good mother to four children, three of whom are married while the other one is single and no longer in school. To help contribute to the family’s daily expenses, one of her daughters works sewing clothes in the garment factory. 

Vong Y. owns a medium-size piece of farmland in the village, where she cultivates rice crops to earn a living. Another source of family income comes from her husband, who is a mobile-phone repairman. He has a shop for selling and mending phones. 

Mrs. Vong Y. is borrowing a loan of $400 for her husband to improve the financial capital of his phone business.

loans.use: To improve the financial capital of her husband's phone business

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is happy with her business. She sells pepper soup, drinks and sachet water. Her peak time for business is in the evenings when her customers leave their jobs and they relax and chat in her restaurant. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She needs a loan of NGN 140,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She has been in this business for the past 12 years. 

She is 55 years old and married with seven children. Some of her children are graduates and the others are married. Her husband sells building materials. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Phea Long Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan is made up of 15 people who are villagers in Kam Nab village in Kandal province. Mrs. Phea L. is the village bank president who has been selected by all the members. The members will use their loans for different purposes.
Mrs. Phea L. is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare piece of land to cultivate rice to support her family. She is a widow who lives with her four children, two of whom are seamstresses in a garment factory while the other two attend the local public school. They work hard but do not earn sufficient income. Therefore, Mrs. Phea L. has decided to ask for a loan to buy some chickens for breeding to start a new business.

All the members of the group are shown in the picture, but some of them are obscured.

loans.use: To buy some chickens for breeding

loans.name: Agnetta

texts.en: Agnetta M. O. is 60 years old. She is married and her husband is a retired man who worked with a printing press. They have seven children between 42 and 25 five years old. Her business is located at Muthurwa, a very busy market near the Central Business District of Nairobi. She has been selling bananas, mangoes, eggs, paw paws and avocadoes for the last 23 years. Her target markets are the Kiosk vendors, hospitals, schools, children's homes and other local people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenges she has are competition and the fluctuating market because of the cold season. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 50,000 to buy more fruits to expand her business. She hopes to change her business some day because it is too tiresome. She also wishes to continue helping to educate her grandchildren.

loans.use: To buy more bananas, mangoes, avocados, paw paws.

loans.name: Biguri Group, Rukungiri

texts.en:
N. Charles appears in the small photo and also appears in the big group photo. He is the leader of his lending group and is married with ten children, six of them still in school. He also takes care of other orphans.

Charles has a business selling cows from Biguri and although the cows are very expensive to buy, he is able to make 200,000/= as profits. For over fifteen years, he has bought cows, kept them for some time and then sold the healthy ones.

Charles’ dream is to be able to buy more cows and start selling to Kampala as well as to have a good looking house. He needs a loan to be able to buy more cows for increased sales. He is such a hardworking man.

loans.use: To buy more cows to sell

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty is 44 years old, married with 4 children. Her husband sells beef to also support their home. She lives in Benin City, Edo State. She sells sarongs and beef. With these combined businesses, she hopes to support her husband to meet the basic needs of the family. She needs a loan amount of NGN 140,000 to purchase more sarongs to sell. She hopes to own a boutique in the future. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Kong

texts.en: Mrs. Kong S. P., 35, is a determined mother who works hard to feed her two children in secondary school. Kong S. P. owns a store inside the local market where she sells chicken porridge which brings in $5 each day to cover her family’s daily living expenses. Her husband helps her in selling food. The current income of this family is not enough to support them so to generate extra revenue, Kong S. P. wants to buy a used car so her husband can get a job as a taxi driver. She is applying for a loan of $1,000 to make this possible.

loans.use: To buy a used car for a taxi service.

loans.name: Erlinda's Group

texts.en:
Erlinda E. is from the village of Brgy.Vista Alegre, Bayombong, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 59 years old. Erlinda is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Erlinda is married and has 7 adult-aged children. To make a living, Erlinda owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over 8 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Erlinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Erlinda is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Erlinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret, aged 48 years, is the mother of three children. She is bread winner for her family and lives in a two-roomed rented house with her children.

Margret has a retail shop business in Masindi, Uganda and has operated her business for eighteen years. She first operated in an open space in the market and later shifted to a shop as the business grew.

This is Margret’s first loan from HOFOKAM and she will use the loan to buy sugar and soap to sell.

loans.use: To buy sugar and soap for her store

loans.name: Bebelie

texts.en: Bebelie Fulon is 28 years old and lives Norala, South Cotabato. She and her husband Dario have one child aged three. She joined CEVI for financial assistance to improve her business in farming and retail. Her loan will be used to buy the needed goods to sell at retail, fertilizers, and e-load — pre-paid cell phone units.

loans.use: Buying goods for her farm and her store

loans.name: Goodluck

texts.en:
Goodluck is happy that his trade is doing well. He makes and sells cooking oil to sell at retail prices. He loves this business because of the profits he makes. The demands for his cooking oil are high and he hopes to meet the demands of his customers. He is a hard working man and he hopes to lift his business and family above poverty. He hopes for a loan amount of NGN 70,000 to purchase more palm fruits to make more cooking oil to sell.

Goodluck lives in Benin City, Edo State. He is 41 years old and married without children. His wife is a teacher and he also supports the home. He says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase palm fruits to make more cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Mon Rours Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan group is made up of twenty people in Ruessel Srok village in Kandal province. Its leader, selected by all the members, is Mrs. Mon R.. She and her husband, Mr. Som Orul Orum, are farmers who own a small piece of land to grow vegetables to sell to support their family. In order to improve production, Mrs. Mon R. decided to apply for a loan to buy bamboo to make supports for growing beans. The couple has three children, one a seamstress in garment factory, and the others in local public school.

loans.use: To buy bamboo to support growing beans

loans.name: Afusat

texts.en:
Afusat is 43 years old, married with 5 children and live in Lagos, Nigeria. She is hard working, believes that women should help their mates and need to support the men in keeping the home. Afusat operates restaurant; she sells drinks and food to make a profit. She has been in the business since 2000. With the profit from the business she could save a little money and assist her husband in running the home. Her husband is a business man and also works hard to meet his financial responsibilities. 

Afusat hopes to expand her business by buying more drinks, food items to sell, she is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase, install and operate a new mill

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Mr. R., 39, is married to That, 31, and they are military police officers. In addition, R. and his wife plant some vegetables at home for sale. They are good parents caring for two school-aged kids. 

R. finds it hard travellng to his work location or anywhere else because he has no vehicle. Thus, he pursues a loan from Kiva’s field partner, HKL. He will buy an old motorcycle for commuting proposes. R. was not available when the photo taken, so his wife is pictured instead.

loans.use: To buy an old motorcycle

loans.name: Robinah

texts.en:
Robinah is 37 years old, is single, and has three children. She is the breadwinner for her family which lives in a rented house. She dreams of owning a residential home, educating her children and setting up a wholesale shop.

Robinah has a retail shop business in Masindi town in Uganda which has been operational for three years.  She came to know about the HOFOKAM credit facility through a friend who encouraged her to grow her business with the easy, accessible and cheap credit funds.

The purpose of the loan is to buy sugar, soap and salt for her shop.

loans.use: To buy sugar, soap and salt for her shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying new sewing machines and work supplies

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en: Nicholas K. W. is twenty six years old, married and has two children aged six years and three years old. His business is located near the busy Marikiti in Nairobi. He sells music CDs and movies. He has been doing this business for the last two years. He says that this business is profitable but the major challenge is that he lacks equipment to download movies as per the customer request. However he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 50,000 to buy a duplicator to be able to burn CDs faster to meet customer demands. He wants to open another business like this one and later venture into transport business. He is a patient and hardworking man.

loans.use: To purchase a duplicator

loans.name: Eguagia

texts.en:
Eguagia is a native of Edo State, Nigeria. He is into the business of tailoring and sales of sarongs. He has been in this business for 12 years. He sews lovely Nigerian and western styles for his customers. He hopes to own a world class tailoring stall in the future. He has been able to care for his family with the proceeds of his business. He is blessed with a child and his wife is a trader. 

Eguagia needs the loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more tailoring materials and sarongs to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring accessories and sarongs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Expanding his field and buying farm supplies

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret has a grinding machine that she uses to grind foodstuffs like tomatoes, pepper, onions and beans. She also makes local soap to sell. She is a lovely and hard working mother. She hopes to lift her business above poverty. She lives in Edo State, Nigeria. She is married and blessed with 6 children. Her children attend school and this makes her happy. 

Margret needs a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase a grinding machine. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a grinding machine

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Selling shoes and women's bags

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane D. has been a LAPO, Sierra Leone client and a credit-union member for two years. She has taken four previous loans, using her previous loans' profit to complete her house project and to assist her husband with her children's schooling. She is asking for a loan of 1,500,000 Leones to expand her fish business.

Jane is 42 years old, married and has four children, three boys and a girl. She lives with her family in Tengbeh town, an area of Freetown, the capital city of Sierra Leone. She helps her family with the profit from her business.

With the assistance of LAPO, SL and Kiva lenders, Jane will use her new loan to purchase more fish and thereafter, use her profit to better her life and that of her family.

loans.use: To purchase fish for sale

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a 50-year-old single mother of three children aged 32, 30 and 20 years though she currently lives with her three grandchildren in a rented house.

Florence sells cereals and dry foods in Masindi, Uganda, a business she has done for twenty years. She first started working in a hotel (restaurant), then sold bananas, and finally switched to selling cereals and dry foodstuffs.

Florence dreams of constructing her own residential house which he thinks is possible with profits from her business and credit from HOFOKAM.

This is Florence’s first loan from HOFOKAM which she intends to use to buy posho (a hot, sticky dough made from maize or cassava), beans, and groundnuts (peanuts) for reselling.

loans.use: To buy posho, beans, and groundnuts for reselling

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Expanding his market garden, buying manure and other supplies

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice sells pastries and drinks to make a living in Benin City. She is doing well in her business. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. Her dream is to own a catering school where she will teach young boys and girls how to bake and make a living for themselves. She is 47 years old and married with 3 children. Her children are making progress in school. 

She needs a loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all her Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Jackson

texts.en: Jackson K. M. is twenty-seven years old. She is married and they have no children yet. Her business is located at a busy market near the Central Business District of Nairobi city. She has been selling second hand clothes to walk in customers for the last three years. She says that this business is profitable and the only major challenge she has is that at times there is low supply making her not maximize her sales because demand is high. However, she works very hard to ensure maximum sales to maximize profits. She is using her loan of Kes 30,000 to buy more clothes to expand her business. In future, she hopes to grow in business and even try out other business ventures like property management and real estates to add her income. She is a very hardworking, humble and caring lady.

loans.use: Clothes.

loans.name: Mr. San Va Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Mr. San V. is the village bank president who has been selected by all the members. The members will use the loan for different purposes. This village bank loan is for 15 people who live in Ruessel Srok village in the Kandal province. 

Mr. San V. and his wife, Mrs. Korng Chhoem, are farmers who own a plot of land and grow and sell vegetables and fruits to support their family. In the vegetable and fruit field, they have a problem because their field has interfile soil. Accordingly, Mr. San V. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer for growing banana trees.
