He is a father of four children, two of whom are construction workers, while the others are enrolled in a local public school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for growing banana trees

loans.name: Nakigalala South Ilado Dorothy Group

texts.en:
I. Dorothy is a 30-year-old married mother of two children, one of whom attends school. She also looks after one dependant who is in school as well.
Dorothy is a hardworking businesswoman who has a retail shop that she has been running for over two years. She is using her loan to purchase retail items, such as sugar, soap, salt, cooking oil and so forth, for resale. She is an encouraging businesswoman whose dream is to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase retail items such as sugar, soap, salt, cooking oil and so forth

loans.name: Adeola

texts.en:
Adeola owns a restaurant; she sells drinks and cooked food to make a living in Lagos State, Nigeria. She has been in the trade for over 19 years. With the profit from the business she could assist her husband in running the home. Her husband is a civil-servant who works very hard to improve on the welfare of his family. Adeola hopes to expand her business in future, she is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more drinks to sell.

Adeola is 42 years old, married with 3 children and live in Lagos Nigeria. She is hard working, she supports her husband in taking good care of his children, like paying of school fees, feeding, clothing and more. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Mambo Kwisha Group, Kampala

texts.en:
Betty N., shown in the small photo at the top left, also appears in the big group photo and is the leader of her group. She has a restaurant business that she has been running for four years, preparing all sorts of dishes like matooke (steamed green plantain), rice, posho (a hot, sticky dough made from maize or cassava), Irish potatoes, and sweet potatoes.

Betty is a widow of 48 years with five children and also cares for three relatives. At the moment, she is renting and she is constructing her business premises just next to her home to reduce transport and renting costs. She has also managed to pay school fees for her children out of her business and with the help of loans.

Betty needs a loan to help with buying more foodstuffs for her restaurant.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for her restaurant

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
G. is the mother of four children aged between 16 and 23. She has been married to Ronaldo G. for 24 years, and the main reason for their business is to ensure that their children receive a good education.
G. has been a member of Kiva partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc. (CEVI), since August 2008 and really enjoys their services, especially the low interest rate. Her loan will be used to buy pig feed (as she has been raising hogs since 2000) and fertilizer for her small half-hectare farm.

loans.use: To buy pig feed and fertilizer for her farm

loans.name: Solomon

texts.en: Solomon is happy selling motor spare parts at retail prices to his customers. He has been in this business since 7 years. He is 30 years old and married with a child. He loves his business and family dearly and he hopes to lift them above poverty. Solomon hopes for a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more motor spare parts to sell. He hopes to grow his business to become bigger and stronger. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more motor spare parts to sell

loans.name: Marlyn's Group

texts.en:
Marlyn A. is from the village of Brgy. Quirino, Bagabag,Nueva Vizcaya. She is 41 years old. Marlyn is the group leader of a 7-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Marlyn is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Marlyn owns & operates a business venture in the food sector making & selling food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling food and drinks for passenger in the bus terminal. Marlyn has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Marlyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marlyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Marlyn is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Marlyn from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Leinh

texts.en:
Mrs. Leinh M., 55, is a local farmer who is assisted by her husband in her farming business. They live and work with their six children in Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. Three of their children are employed in different jobs and provide a small income to support the family. Leinh M. and her husband make about $3 USD per day. They work hard every day because they need income to support their family. Leinh M. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer and a pumping machine for her farming business.
Note: Mrs. Leinh's husband is shown in the picture above.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and a pumping machine

loans.name: Joshua

texts.en: Joshua N. K. is twenty two years old, married to a housewife and they do not have any children yet. His business is located at Kiganjo mali area in Nairobi. He has been selling flour, sugar, rice, detergents etc for one year now. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is financial constraints. However he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy more general items to expand his business. He hopes to be a wholesaler in future. He is very hardworking and patient.

loans.use: Flour, sugar, rice, soap etc

loans.name: Hang's Group

texts.en:
Hằng Thị T. Đỗ is 41 years old. She lives in Duc Tu village, Dong Anh, Ha Noi, with her husband and two children. She breeds pigs and breeds poultry. Her husband is a driver. They have a monthly income of about 4.000.000 Vietnamese dong. 

Ms Hang has taken part in SEDA for four years. She is the group leader of a seven–member group loan with Kiva partner SEDA and repays on time. In the next loan cycle, she would like to borrow 5.014.000 VND (or about $265) to breed pigs and poultry in the hope that it will make a profit so that her family may afford to buy more good furniture.

 About the other borrowers in her group:

 Hien T. P. is 50 years old. She breeds poultry and cooks wine. She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND to buy rice for cooking wine.

 Oanh T. N. is 28 years old. She breeds chickens and wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND to buy chicken feed.

 Thuan T. N. is 51 years old. She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND to breed poultry.

 Vui T. Hoang is 53 years old. She wants to borrow 6.322.000 to buy chicken feed.

 Loan T. N. is 52 years old. She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND for a small business.

 Ngu T. H. P. is 30 years old. She wants to borrow 5.014.000 VND to invest in her business.

loans.use: For pig breeding and poultry breeding

loans.name: Noreen

texts.en:
Noreen Y. is from the village of Cabaruan, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 32 years old. Noreen is single and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Noreen owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Noreen has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Noreen joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Noreen is requesting a new loan of 15000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Noreen from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Garri (cassava flakes) is a staple food in Nigeria and it is gotten from cassava. It can be eaten with soup, peanuts, coconut and beans. She also sells tubers of yam. She is a hard working woman and she is so determined to lift her business above poverty. Charity is married to a commercial driver. They are blessed with 5 children. She needs a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more garri to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more garri (cassava flakes) to sell

loans.name: Nyoka

texts.en:
Nyoka J. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables at the market and is requesting a loan to purchase tomatoes and onions to sell.  Nyoka is 29 years old and married to a soldier. She has six children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. 

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase tomatoes and onions to sell

loans.name: Lenh

texts.en:
Mr. Lenh L., 41, lives in a commune located in the rural area of Phnom Penh. He is disabled, having lost his right foot from civil war. To earn a living, he owns a pond, which is full of the lotus he grows. He will harvest and sell to buyers when the lotus is mature. He also depends on the income from his wife, who sells a few groceries and vegetables in the village. 

Lenh L. will be using his loan to buy fertilizers to fatten his lotus and the rest will accumulate more inventory for his wife’s grocery store. Lenh L. and his wife are pictured at their house.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and grocery inventory

loans.name: Bassam

texts.en:
Bassam is a 47-year-old married man with 3 school-age children. He has been working as a car painter for the past 35 years and he opened his own shop 13 years ago. Bassam has taken a first loan from Ameen and he is pleased with his decision. He said that the loan amount was appropriate for his work in the last year. 

And today, Bassam is asking to take another Kiva loan of $1,500 to help expand his business by purchasing an air compressor and be able to meet the requirement of his clients and make a good income for his family.

loans.use: purchasing an air compressor

loans.name: Agness

texts.en:
Agness is a very hard working woman. She is 30 years old, married with a child and lives in Lagos where she does the business of selling of foodstuffs and drinks. She has been in the business for 3 years now. She hopes for expansion and improvement in her business in future, that will impact her business and family life positively. 

Agness is requesting for the loan amount of NGN 70,000 to purchase more food stuff and drinks to sell as this will attract discount and increase sales. She hopes to repay back her loan at due date. She appreciates all lenders for their wonderful support.

loans.use: To purchase more food stuff and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Keji

texts.en:
Keji Jerisio,32, is married to a husband who is a teacher. They have five children who go to school. Keji has a business selling a local brew and beer and is requesting a loan to purchase crates of beer to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase crates of beer to sell

loans.name: 07.05.04 Hoang Hoa Group

texts.en:
Vinh H. T. is 42, and married with two school-aged children. She lives in the town of H. Hoa Thanh Hoa. Vinh is the leader of a four-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. To making a living, Vinh raises cattL. for saL.. She has been doing this for three years and earns approximately 1.300.000 VND a month. 

In 2003, Vinh joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3.000.000 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell and is now requesting a new loan of 5.000.000 VND for the same purpose. The loan is the fourth loan she will have taken out from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Vinh plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:

1.  L. T. Bac is a 34-year-old woman who is requesting a 5.000.000 VND loan to support her retail store.

2.  L. T. Phuong is a 41-year-old woman who is requesting a 5.000.000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.

3.  H. T. Hang is a 42-year-old woman who is requesting a 5.000.000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock.

About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: The mission of the Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Vinh H. T. ( 003) là 42 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở H. Hoa Thanh Hoa.  Vinh là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 07.05.04 H. Hoa - Thanh Hoa (07.05.04 H. Hoa).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gia súc để bán.  Vinh thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 3 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Vinh kiếm được khoảng 1.300.000 VND.  Vào 2003, Vinh đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Vinh đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3.000.000 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5.000.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  L. T. Bac (038) là 34 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực bán lẻ.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là kinh doanh cửa hiệu bán lẻ chuyên dụng.


2.  L. T. Phuong (006) là 41 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


3.  H. T. Hang (042) là 42 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5.000.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell

loans.name: Lweza South Kajimu Ronah Group

texts.en: K. Ronah is twenty-two years old and represents the five-member Lweza South Group. She lives with her husband and two school-age children. Ronah owns a beauty salon that she has operated for four years. She will use the loan to stock salon products — hair treatments, shampoo, hair oil, etc. — to boost her business. She is encouraged by the loan and hopes to be able to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: To add to her inventory of hair products

loans.name: Daki

texts.en:
Daki V. is currently in the business of selling charcoal at home. She is requesting a loan to stock crates of beer to sell. 

Daki is 35 years old and is married to a nurse. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Affection Plus Group

texts.en:
Affection Plus is a group of 27 owners of small businesses chaired by Albert. Its members are jointly liable for loans granted by Kiva to grow their businesses.

Albert D. is determined to be a successful businessman. He sells used clothing at a market located in the eastern part of Kinshasa. He became a microentrepreneur in 2004. Albert has already received three loans from the microfinance institution HOPE DRC and fully repaid them. 

He intends to use this loan to expand his inventory. He will buy used clothing to resell at a profit. Currently he earns a profit of $25 a week. He will seek to make more profit by selling more products.

Albert is 42 years old, married and the father of four children aged 7 to 14. All of them attend school.

loans.use: To expand his inventory. He will buy used clothing to resell at a profit.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Zareena wants a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle). Mehraj wants a loan to buy quilts to sell. Rukhsana wants a loan to buy spare parts for motorbikes for her spare parts sales business. Parveen wants a loan to buy construction supplies (cement, bricks) to resell. Parveen is the group leader for the above-mentioned ladies. They all belong to a city called Lahore, famous in Pakistan for its historical places and its Punjabi foods. 

Parveen manages her cloth-selling business and she prepares embroidered clothes as well. Both businesses give her good earning which helps her to meet the family's expenses, together with her husband. She purchases the cloth from different areas such as “Ichra & Azam Market” because of its good quality stuff and cheap prices. 

Parveen's husband's name is M. B. and he is a driver, driving a rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle) belonging to someone else. At the end of the day he gives him Pak Rs. 300 which is the least amount that can feed his family. Therefore Parveen has decided to ask for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw for her husband so he gets the full amount of his struggle and can manage the expenses.

loans.use: To buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle)

loans.name: Poni

texts.en:
Poni C. is currently in the business of selling green vegetables at the market. She is requesting a loan to purchase bags of beans and pulses (groundnuts, peas or cowpeas) to sell. 

Poni is 30 years old and married to an engineer. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Purchase bags of beans and pulses (groundnuts, pea or cowpeas) to sell

loans.name: Modupe

texts.en:
Modupe is 52 years old. Her husband is a civil servant and they have 5 children. Her children attend school and this gives her joy. She sells jewelries, clothes and body cream to earn a living in Benin City, Edo state. She needs a loan amount of NGN 70,000 to purchase more jewelry, clothes and body cream to sell.

Her dream is to see her business expand and also to see her family have a better standard of living. She says thanks to all her lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more jewelries, body cream and clothes to sell

loans.name: Doru

texts.en:
Doru S. is currently in the business of brewing and selling local alcohol and is requesting a loan to stock more brewing materials like yeasts etc.  Doru is 42 years old and is married to a policeman. She has two children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to send her children to school.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more brewing materials like yeasts etc

loans.name: Salma's Group

texts.en:
Parveen wants a loan to buy construction supplies (cement, bricks) for her construction supply-selling business. Khursheed wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. Tahira wants a loan to buy clothes for her clothes-selling business. Abida wants a loan to buy materials (lentils, cooking oil and rice) for her food stand. 

Salma is the group leader of the above-mentioned ladies. They all live in a city called Lahore, famous in Pakistan for its historical places and its Punjabi foods. She is a mother of five kids: three daughters and two sons. All of them are enrolled in school and are getting an education. She is an uneducated lady but She wants to raise her kids with an education because it's necessary for their future. Her husband supports him in her dream by getting up early to bring the children in to school. 

She operates a sewing business and her husband operates her dairy business. They both earn well from their businesses. They save a part of their income in a "committee" for their children and will utilize this money for their higher education. Currently, they need a loan to buy another dairy cow to expand their dairy business.

loans.use: To buy another dairy cow for dairy business

loans.name: Tserenpil

texts.en: Tserenpil is 47 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. They have been living together in their current home for 14 years. Her two daughters are university students. Currently, Tserenpil operates a clothing trading business at a local market. She sells a variety of clothes such as men and women's clothes. She purchases the products in Ereen, a Chinese border town. Tserenpil started her business in 1999 with a working capital of 500,000 tugrugs (~ 351 USD). She has built her business to a consistent level and attributes its success to her strong selling and communication skills. Today, her working capital exceeds 2,400,000 tugrugs (~ 1688 USD). With her business profit, she pays her daughters' university fees. Tserenpil is a very hardworking person and she says, “I am working hard to improve my family's quality of life and continue to pay my daughters' university fees.” She is requesting a 3,000,000-tugrug loan to purchase more clothing from China for her business.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing

loans.name: Hizar

texts.en:
Hizar is a 23-year-old married woman and mother of one young child. In order to help with her family’s expenses, Hizar has opened a small teaching business from her home; she started receiving the village children who needs education supports since 2007 at her home where she has prepared a special room for this purpose. She' very happy with her business because she's able to help the children and she feels that it's a mission in her life. 

Today, Hizar is requesting to borrow $700 to build a new education room with all the preparation related such as stationary, new chairs and tables, board etc. because she's planning to receive more students and expand her business. And she hopes that her family status level will be also developed as a result of the loan.

loans.use: build a new education room

loans.name: Ade

texts.en:
Ade sells foodstuffs like pepper, rice, beans, melons and tomato paste at retail prices to her customers. She hopes for expansion in her business. She has a good relationship with LAPO.

Ade is requesting for a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She is married with 4 children. Her husband is a building contractor and he also supports the home. She is grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Juan A. is currently in the business of selling ice cream and groundnut paste at home and is requesting a loan to purchase onions and cooking oil to sell.  Juan is 32 years old and is married to a soldier. She has five children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a shop.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase onions and cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence C. is a 45-year-old industrious lady married to Mr. Benard, who runs a laundry business. They have three children. Christabel and Francis are in secondary school and Festus is in primary school. They stay in Shinyalu estate in Kakamega town.

Florence has been in the tailoring business for the last seven years. She runs her business from Shibuye market in Kakamega town. She learned about KADET Ltd through a friend who is an existing client. This is her third loan from KADET Ltd and she hopes to use the money to increase her stock of materials for tailoring work. 

She aspires to open a wholesale shop selling textile materials and to diversify to sugarcane farming to increase the scale of her business.

loans.use: To buy more textile materials for her tailoring work.

loans.name: Otgonsuren

texts.en: Otgonsuren is 52 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in Arhangai province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, which is a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent.  During the day, she operates a meat trading business in her home province. Otgonsuren has been operating her meat trading business and her dairy selling business since 2002, and has steadily expanded her business. At the beginning, her working capital was approximately 100,000 tugrugs (~ 70 USD), but through her hard work and determination, today Otgonsuren's working capital exceeds 2,000,000 tugrugs (~ 1407 USD). Otgonsuren has great communication skills and is a very hard working person. She is requesting a 500,000-tugrug loan to purchase a large amount of meat to sell for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase meat for her butcher shop

loans.name: Iyabo

texts.en:
For the past five years, Iyabo has owned a shop in Lagos, Nigeria where she sells foodstuffs, groceries and drinks profitably at retail prices, managing the business with the help of her husband. She also assists her husband in keeping the home. Iyabo is now requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more foodstuffs, groceries and drinks to sell. The additional profit from the business will enable her to save and reinvest in the business, which will lead to expansion in the future.

Iyabo is 30 years old, married and blessed with three children, ages three, five, and seven years old, all doing fine. She hopes to support her husband in sponsoring their education and expresses her huge gratitude to all Kiva lenders for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs, groceries and drinks to sell.

loans.name: Yoeum

texts.en:
Mrs. P. established a small family home four years ago in the middle of the best territory of the capital city of Phnom Penh, and she has given birth to seven children, two of whom are married. Three of her children are employed with different occupations: one is a vegetable vendor, one sells clams, and one is a building worker. 

Mrs. P. currently sells different kinds of vegetables in the market to earn a living, and her husband assists her in selling her produce. P. has a son who wants to get married and he needs to have a wedding party, but he doesn't have money. P. has requested a loan to allow her son to make a wedding party possible. (Mrs. P. was not available on this day, so her husband is pictured instead.)

loans.use: To make a wedding party possible

loans.name: Pita

texts.en:
Pita E. is currently in the business of selling beer and local brew at home and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell. Pita is 40 years old and is widowed. She has six children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bar at the market.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna has been selling tubers of yam for the past ten years. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. Yams in Nigeria can be eaten boiled, fried and roasted. 

Anna is married with four children. Her husband is a pastor and he also supports their home.

She asks for a loan amount of 120,000 NGN to purchase more tubers of yams to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tubers of yam to sell

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty D. is from the village of Caputol, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. She is 65 years old. Betty is married and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, Betty owns and operates a fruit and vegetable vending business by planting and harvesting crops for sale in the local community. Betty is just starting this business. 

In 2005, Betty joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Betty has successfully repaid a previous loan  from PMPC. Betty is requesting a new loan of 35,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and to be used as working capital. This loan will be the tenth loan taken out by Betty from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.\n\n*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and for use as working capital

loans.name: Jared Ochieng

texts.en:
Jared G., 26 years old, is an experienced artisan. He is married to Jane Achieng, a tailor, and they have a two-month-old baby girl. Jared moulds and assembles charcoal burners (locally known as ‘Jiko’) in Lurambi, Kakamega town. Jared enjoys a booming business because of his high quality burners, and also because of the popularity of the burners in the area. 

Jared is grateful that he is able to access credit from KADET to improve his business. He will use the loan to buy raw materials for the burners, for example, iron sheets and molding materials. His wish is to find a lender to enable him advance his business 

Jared has a dream to diversify to retail business by opening a shop and also to help his wife expand her tailoring business. They believe that through this loan, they will be able to generate more income and improve their living standards.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for charcoal burner manufacturing

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn T. is from Mahayag Zamboangan del Sur. She is 32 years old and married with three children. To make living, she manages her business, which is a sari-sari (variety retail) store. Her husband is a farmer and supports their daily basic needs. She has managed her business for more than two years, and she and her husband earn approximately 7,000 PHP a month.

She successfully repaid her previous loan of 8,000 PHP from PMPC. As of now, she has a new loan of 10,000 PHP from PMPC and this loan is intended for her to use as additional capital. Merlyn is on her third cycle of obtaining loans from PMPC.

loans.use: Additional capital for her retail store

loans.name: Roda

texts.en:
Roda T. is currently in the business of selling various items in her retail store, such as sweets and biscuits. She is requesting a loan to stock bags of sugar, beans, etc., in her store. Roda is 39 years old and is married to a peasant. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock bags of sugar, beans and other items for resale in her store

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis O. is an industrious man who is married to Millicent, who runs a grocery store. They have three children: Veronicah, who has just finished college; Daisy, who is in grade 3 of primary school; and Elvis, who is in nursery school. 

Francis runs a business of selling shoes in Lake Market, an open air populous market in Kisumu City, a very strategic point for this type of business.  Francis has been in this business for 11 years and he learned about KADET from the staff of World Vision. He stocks men’s shoes only, and thus most of his clients are men. The loan he has applied for will be used to add more stock of men’s shoes for sale.

Francis, who believes in honesty, has a dream of opening a shop for his wife. His dream is to give his children the best education and also to expand his business.

loans.use: To buy more shoes for resale

loans.name: Reuben

texts.en:
Reuben O., 31, is married and the father of two children. His wife, Lilian, sells clothes in one of the local markets. Reuben runs an office stationery business in the heart of Kisumu town and gets numerous customers from schools and other institutions of learning within Kisumu. He supplies them with writing materials and other office stationery. It is keeping such contacts that has allowed him to excel in his business and he has continued to experience growth for the past four years.

Due to the increasing number of customers, Reuben has had to look for a financier to help him meet his customers' demands. He therefore joined Kadet Ltd., and applied for his first loan, after meeting the requirements. He intends to use the loan to buy more stationery to distribute to his customers, the majority being schools.  

His dream is to become a prime supplier of stationery to different schools within Kisumu City and neighboring towns. He also hopes to boost his wife’s business, which will increase the family's income.

loans.use: To buy stationery and other office supplies for resale

loans.name: Jared

texts.en:
Jared O. is 20 years old and married to Millicent, and they have a three-year-old daughter. Jared runs a shoe sales business in Oile Market, an open air populous market in Kisumu City. He has been in this business for the past ten years. He buys the shoes from vendors in Nairobi, the capital city, and sells them at a profit in Kisumu, about 400 kilometres from Nairobi. He sells shoes for men and women, though men's shoes sell faster than ladies.

Jared learned about KADET Ltd from a friend who is an existing client, and this is his third loan. He is optimistic about the loan since he has had ambitions of growing the business in scale, as he can now purchase stock in large quantities. He therefore intends to use the loan to increase his shoe inventory and also to buy plastics chairs for hire.

From the profits made, he intends to buy one sewing machine for his wife who makes clothes. Jared, who describes himself as “ambitious and hardworking”, has a dream of helping his wife open a tailoring school.

loans.use: To increase his shoe inventory

loans.name: Masheruka Siimuka Coffee Group, Bushenyi

texts.en:
T. Evangelista, shown in the small picture, also appears in the group photo as the group leader. She is a 36-year-old widow who sells coffee in Kashunga trading center, Bushenyi district, to earn her daily subsistence.

Evangelista has been plying this trade for the last fifteen years and she credits her choice to sell dry coffee as her winning formula. In a month, she is able to make 25,000 Ugandan shillings, a figure which has not substantially consolidated her business.

Evangelista’s future plan is to plant her own coffee, whereupon she will be in a position to sell at a higher price. Longer term, she also hopes she will be able to educate all of her five children.

Evangelista needs a loan to be able to mulch her coffee plantations, since this improves the stock and general turnover.

loans.use: To mulch her coffee plantations for improved output

loans.name: Kellpiopas

texts.en:
Kellpiopas M. is currently in the business of selling fish at the market and is requesting a loan to stock beans and maize flour to sell. Kellpiopas is 32 years old and is married to an engineer. She has four children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock beans and maize flour to sell

loans.name: Tom

texts.en:
Tom O. is 32 years old and married to Susan Atieno, who sells milk. They have three children: Stacy, who is 6 years old and in grade one of primary school; Kingsley, who is 3 years old and in baby class; and Winsley, who is 3 months old. 

He runs a shoe-selling business in Oile Market, an open-air populous market in Kisumu City. He has been in this business for the last three years. Tom gets the shoes from vendors in the capital city, Nairobi, and sells them at a profit in Kisumu. He sells shoes for both genders. 

Tom learned about KADET Ltd. from a friend who is an existing client. This is his third loan. He intends to use the loan to increase his stock of ladies shoes, since the season for school shoes is over. He will also buy sports shoes since most of his clients have been asking for them.

From the profits made, he intends to open a dairy shop for his wife. Tom, a hardworking and industrious man, has a dream of expanding his business by having a variety of shoes. He also hopes to have his children well-educated.

loans.use: To buys sports and ladies shoes

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa sells slightly used bags. She has been in this business for ten years. With the proceeds of her business, she supports her children's education and also supports her husband with other house expenses. She is requesting a loan amount of 170,000 NGN to purchase more slightly used bags to sell. 

She is 42 years old and married with five children. She is a member of the Igbo tribe. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more used bags to sell

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Hawa H. is currently in the business of selling bags of charcoal on a wholesale basis and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Hawa is 49 years old and widowed. She has six children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a charcoal store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Thy

texts.en:
Mrs. Thy C. is a villager who lives in Chrouy Dang village in the Kandal province. Mrs. Thy C. and her husband are farmers who own a plot of land and cultivate rice to earn a living for their family. On this farm, they do not have enough money to support their farming crops. Thus, Mrs. Thy C. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer and rice seed. 

Mrs. Thy C. is 40 years old and the mother of six children, two of whom are seamstresses in the garment factory, three are attending the local school, while the youngest one is 5 years old. Her husband is on the right in the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and rice seed

loans.name: Chidinma

texts.en:
Chidinma sells cooking oil to make a living in Benin City, Edo state. Cooking oil is essential in the preparation of soup in Nigeria. She has been in this business for seven years. 

This business has helped her financial position and she is able to contribute to her family's upkeep. She is asking for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more cooking oil to sell.

She is 49 years old and married with eight children. Her children are doing well in school. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cooking oil to sell

loans.name: Yadmaa

texts.en:
Yadmaa is 47 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Uvs province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.

Yadmaa’s husband operates a wooden product manufacturing business. He produces wooden products such as doors, frames, chairs and tables for a ger, and Yadmaa sells them to their customers in the countryside. They have been operating their business since 2000, and their business has grown over the years and they have gained much experience.

Yadmaa has good communication skills and she says, “As a result of our hard work and determination from previous years, our family's quality of life has improved. We have been planning to create our own workplace in the future.”

Yadmaa is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug loan to purchase timber at a wholesales price for their business.

loans.use: To purchase timber for her family's carpentry business

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is a 33-year-old married man and father of one young child. Ten years ago, when he was young, he started learning the hairdressing occupation as a new career in his life. He became a talented hairdresser and in 2006, he started working on his own. He opened his own barber shop and receives clients from his village and its surroundings. He is the only provider for his family with his business. 

Today, Joseph is asking to borrow $1,000 to buy additionA. supplies needed, such as hair gels, shaving soap, etc., in order to expand his client base and increase his business productivity and income as a result.

loans.use: Buy additional supplies

loans.name: Batsuuri

texts.en:
Batsuuri is 30 years old and lives with his wife and daughter in Uvs province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. They have been living together in their current home for fifteen years.

Batsuuri operates a vegetable trading business at a local market. He plants vegetables in the spring, and takes harvest in the autumn, and his wife sells the vegetables at a local market. Batsuuri keeps the harvest in a warehouse and sells those vegetables until the next spring of each year.

Batsuuri has a hectare of land on which to grow vegetables. He has been operating his business since 1997 and has expanded the business and has became an experienced vegetable trader. He is a very hardworking person and has many plans for the future. Batsuuri says, “I would like to purchase my own plot of land and build a warehouse which has a capacity of twenty tons of vegetables.”

Currently, Batsuuri has five tons of potatoes in the warehouse, but now he hasn’t any carrots or rutabagas to sell. He is requesting a 400,000 tugrug loan to purchase rutabagas, carrots, onions and cabbages at wholesales price for his vegetable-trading business.

loans.use: To purchase more vegetables to sell

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is 32 years old. Her husband is a commercial driver and they have 2 children. Her children attend school and this gives her joy. She has a good relationship with LAPO. She sells drinks and groceries to earn a living in Benin City, Edo state. She needs a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell.

Her dream is to see her business expand and also to see her family have a better standard of living. She says thanks to all her lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and groceries to sell

loans.name: Gisèle

texts.fr: Z. Gisèle est née le 04 Mai 1984 et vit depuis 8 ans au quartier Djassin, dans le troisième arrondissement de Porto-Novo au Bénin. Mariée à AFATON Marius, Gisèle est mère d'un enfant. La famille vit ensemble et le couple assure les différentes charges familiales. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Gisèle mène comme activité, la vente de vêtements, de parfums et aussi de glacières de façon ambulante. Gisèle s'approvisionne à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Gisèle exerce cette activité depuis 10 ans et a déjà bénéficié de trois crédits de ALIDé. Gisèle a bien remboursé les trois crédits qu'elle avait obtenu. Gisèle aimerait augmenter le volume de son activité et mieux satisfaire toutes les demandes de sa clientèle. Mais Gisèle ne réunit pas les moyens financiers nécessaires pour y arriver. C'est la raison pour laquelle Gisèle sollicite un quatrième prêt de ALIDé, afin d'augmenter son fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
Gisèle Z. was born on May 4, 1984. She has been living for eight years in the neighborhood of Djassin, the third arrondissement [municipal district] of Porto-Novo in Benin. Gisèle is married to Marius Afaton and is the mother of one child. The family lives together and the couple provides for the different needs of the family. To meet her needs, Gisèle’s business activity is the door-to-door sale of clothing, perfumes and also of iceboxes. She gets her supplies in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She has been practicing this activity for 10 years and has already received three loans from ALIDé. She has fully reimbursed the three loans she received. Gisèle would like to increase the volume of her activity to better meet all the demands of her customers. However she cannot bring together the necessary financial means to succeed. For this reason, she is requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé in order to increase her working capital.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of clothing and iceboxes

loans.name: Bertsetseg

texts.en:
Bertsetseg is 34 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Uvs province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the  Mongolian nomadic tent. Her two children attend a local secondary school, and her husband is a herder, who has a few head of livestock, as well as operating a transportation business. Bertsetseg and her family have been living together in their current home for seven years. 

Bertsetseg operates a food product trading business at a local market, and she purchases the products from Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, at wholesale prices and resells them for a profit. She has been operating business since 2005 from a 5 ton shipping container at a local market. Bertsetseg has been planning to open own food store in the future. She has a good communication skills and she is a very hard working person. She has many plans on the future and says, “I would like to save money for my children's education fees. In addition, my dream is to build our own garage at our land and to build our own house for my family. ” She is requesting a 3,500,000 tugrug (~ 2465 USD) loan to purchase food products including biscuits, noodles, sugar and beverages for her food trading business.

loans.use: To purchase food products to sell

loans.name: Lydiah

texts.en:
Lydiah N. is a forty-five-year-old mother of three children aged 12, 11 and 8 years. The children are all in primary school at a local village school. Lydiah is married to Matthews Alusiola, a farmer. They live in Shinyalu area of Kakamega town.

Lydiah sells cereals in Shibuye, an open air populous market in the outskirts of Kakamega town. She went into this type of business five years ago and this is her third loan from KADET Ltd. She intends to use the money to purchase more stock of beans, maize, and other cereals. She hopes to get support from Kiva lenders through KADET Ltd to enable her to expand her business. 

She aspires to buy a plot of land and construct a permanent residential home as a way of improving her living standards.

loans.use: To buy more stock of cereals; Maize and Beans.

loans.name: Eliane

texts.en:
Eliane is a 41 year old married woman and mother of 3 school-aged children. In 2008 she decided to open a small mini-market to help her husband with the heavy expenses of life. She offers in her grocery shop various food products, soft drinks, chocolates, chips, etc. Her mini-market is situated in a busy area, so she has been able, during these 2 years, to have a growing number of clients pass by her shop and buy all types of food products. 

Today, Eliane is requesting to borrow $1,200 to increase her store’s inventory and continue catering to her clients. She also reported that she is certain that both her business productivity and income will be increased as a result of taking this loan.

loans.use: To increase her store’s inventory

loans.name: Alifath

texts.fr: Née en 1972 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin, A. Alifath est mariée à SAGBO Tidjani, un pêcheur. Le couple a sept enfants à charge, dont trois sont leurs propres enfants. Tous les enfants sont scolarisés. La famille vit à Louho, un quartier de Porto-Novo. Alifath vient en aide à son mari en ce qui concerne les différentes charges familiales. Pour faire face à ses différentes charges, Alifath prépare et vend de la nourriture (pâte de maïs accompagnée de sauce) à son domicile. Alifath s'approvisionne au marché de Ouando à Porto-Novo, et aussi à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Il y a près de 17 ans que Alifath mène cette activité. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé ayant déjà obtenu trois prêts qui ont été bien remboursés. Alifath sollicite un quatrième prêt en vue d'augmenter le stock de ses produits et de pouvoir mieux faire face à la demande nombreuse de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1972 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin, A. Alifath is married to SAGBO Tidjani, a fisherman. The couple have seven children to support. Three of the children are their own; all of them are in school. The family lives in Louho, a district of Porto-Novo. Alifath helps out her husband where it concerns the various family expenses. To cope with her various expenses, Alifath makes and sells food (corn polenta served with sauce) out of her home. She gets her supplies from the Ouando market in Porto-Novo, and also in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She has been in this business for nearly seventeen years. She is a previous ALIDé client having already obtained three loans, which have been repaid. She's requesting a fourth loan for increasing her stock of products and to be able to cope better with the numerous demands of her customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sacks of corn and condiments for making sauces

loans.name: Nouboukpo

texts.en: Nouboukpo A. is married and has one child. He lives and works in Lomé, Togo, painting automobiles. He began this business in 2002 and is now asking for his first loan from WAGES. He will use this loan to purchase paint for the vehicles he paints for his customers. With your help, Mr. A. will be able to offer a wide selection of paints to his customers. It is with great hope that this loan will allow Mr. A.’s business to prosper and will help him support his family.

loans.use: Purchase of paint for vehicles

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of corn

loans.name: Stella

texts.en:
Stella is happy with her business. She sells pepper soup, drinks and sachet water. Her peak time for business is in the evenings when her customers finish their jobs and they relax and chat in her restaurant.

She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She needs the loan amount of NGN 100,000 to purchase more drinks and a fridge. She has been in this business for the past 7 years. 

She is married with children. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and a fridge

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of clothing

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: Doris is 43 years old. Her husband sells firewood and they have children. Her children attend school and this gives her joy. She has a good relationship with LAPO. To earn a living, she sells drinks and groceries in Benin City, Edo State. She needs a loan of 150,000 nairas to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. Her dream is to see her business expand and also see her family have a better standard of living. She says thanks to all her lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of salt

loans.name: Loveth

texts.en:
Loveth is a native of Edo State, Nigeria. She is into the business of tailoring and sells sarongs. She has been in this business for 17 years. She sews lovely Nigerian and western styles for her customers. She hopes to own a world class tailoring stall in the future. She has been able to care for her family with the proceeds of her business. She is blessed with children. She is 36 years old.

Loveth needs a loan of 50,000 nairas to purchase more tailoring materials and sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials and sarongs to sell

loans.name: Afi Enyonam

texts.en: Afi Enyonam A. is a trained cook. She lives in Lomé, Togo with her husband and two children. She now works selling Fan Milk products, a variety of frozen milk products that are very popular when facing the hot Togolese sun. Mrs. A. began selling these products in 1999 through her business called “Gigovi.” She is now asking for her first loan from WAGES, which she will use to resupply her stock of Fan Milk products. This loan will help Mrs. A.’s business grow and keep her customers cool and satisfied.

loans.use: Purchase of Fan Milk Products for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of a motorcycle

loans.name: Tsolmontsog

texts.en:
Tsolmontsog is 33 years old and lives with his wife and son in Uvs province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife, Amarjargal, is a music teacher in a local secondary school and her salary is  220,000 tugrugs (~ 155 USD). 

Tsolmontsog operates a transportation business in his home province, and transports customers between Uvs province and Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Tsolmontsog has been operating his business since 2003, and has been trading products from Ereen, a Chinese border city, for the local customers. He has been planning to work hard and purchase a new micro bus for his business in the future. 

Tsolmontsog is a friendly person who has great communication skills. He says, “I would like to purchase a brand new micro bus so I will have a total of three micro buses for my transportation business. ” Tsolmontsog is requesting a 2,000,000  tugrug loan to purchase more inventory from Ereen and resell them for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience is 41 years old. Her husband is a plumber and they have four children. Her children attend school and this gives her joy. She has a good relationship with LAPO. To earn a living, she sells drinks and groceries in Benin City, Edo State. She needs a loan of 60,000 nairas to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Doflin

texts.fr: Née en 1975 à Adjarra dans le département de l'Ouémé, H. Doflin vit depuis 15 ans environs à Adjarra - Tossouhou à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à KPINKPONSOUHOU Hounsouhoui, un guérisseur,  Doflin est mère de quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble et le couple assure les différentes charges familiales. Il y a près de 15 ans que Doflin vend des céréales (maïs, haricot, etc.) au marché de Adjarra. De façon secondaire, Doflin vend également du poisson. C'est à Ikpinlè, un marché de vente de produits vivriers au Bénin, que Doflin fait ses provisions. Doflin a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, et les a tous bien remboursés. Doflin sollicite un troisième prêt de ALIDé, en vue de renforcer son activité et de mieux répondre à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de la clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1975 in Adjarra, in Ouémé County, H. Doflin has lived for about fifteen years in Adjarra – Tossouhou, in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. Married to KPINKPONSOUHOU Hounsouhoui, a healer, she is the mother of four children, who are all in school. The family lives together, and the couple ensure that their various family expenses are covered. For almost fifteen years ago, Dolfin has been selling grains (corn, beans, etc.) at the Adjarra market. Secondarily, she also sells fish. She gets her provisions from Ikpinlè, a market selling staple goods in Benin. She has already obtained two loans from ALIDé and has repaid them both. She's requesting a third loan from ALIDé for bolstering her business and responding better to the burgeoning number of demands from customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying sacks of corn and beans

loans.name: Monday

texts.en:
Monday has two businesses: he is a commercial motorcycle rider and he also sells beef. With these businesses he hopes to meet the basic needs of his family.

Monday’s motorcycle is getting old and he needs a new one to be able to render his services to his customers. He needs a loan of NGN 60,000 to purchase a new motorcycle.

Monday is 50 years old and married with four children. His wife also sells beef to support their home. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of general food products

loans.name: Adwoa Juliana

texts.en: Adwoa Juliana A. is a single mother with one child. She lives in Lomé, Togo, and sells charcoal out of her home. She began this business in 2004 and is now asking for her first loan from WAGES. She will use this loan to replenish her stock of charcoal for resale. This loan will help the continued growth of Ms. A.’s business and allow her to support her family.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for resale

loans.name: Philomène

texts.fr: Née en 1982, A. Philomène vit depuis une vingtaine d'année au quartier Djassin Daho dans le troisième arrondissement de la ville de Porto-Novo au Bénin. Philomène est mariée à HOUESSOU Honoré, un vendeur de gravier et est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble et le couple assure les différentes charges de la famille. Philomène n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Pour assurer ses besoins et ceux de ses enfants, Philomène vend depuis 15 ans, du poisson frais au marché Ouando à Porto-Novo. Philomène s'approvisionne à Djassin Tokpa, un quartier de Porto-Novo. C'est la première fois que Philomène sollicite un crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qui lui servira à augmenter son fonds de roulement et à renforcer son activité, pour mieux faire face à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1982, A. Philomène has lived for twenty years in the Djassin Daho quarter in the third district of the city of Porto-Novo in Benin. She is married to HOUESSOU Honoré, a gravel seller, and is the mother of four children, who are all in school. The family lives together, and the couple ensure that their various family expenses are covered. Philomène did not attend school. To make sure her needs and those of her children are met, she has been selling fresh fish for fifteen years at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo. She gets her supplies in the Djassin Tokpa quarter, in Porto-Novo. This is the first time Philomène is requesting a loan from ALIDé. It will be used to augment her working capital and to bolster her business. This will allow her to cope with the demands of her customers.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying fresh fish

loans.name: Prosper Business Group

texts.en:
Theresa K. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called Prosper Business. She is 44 years old, married, and has four children who range in age from 8 to 22 years old. Theresa also cares for a niece and a nephew.  She did not have the opportunity to go to school due to poverty. For 10 years, Theresa has been selling general food items such as sardines, mayonnaise and milk at the Moulton Corner Market in Brewerville in Monrovia, Liberia. She provides flexible hours for her customers, which keeps them returning.  

Theresa plans to use her 10,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 50,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more sardines, milk, and mayonnaise. Her goal is to grow her business into a store and help her children get a higher education.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Theresa is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country.  Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship.  LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts an emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more sardines, milk, and mayonnaise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying miscellenous goods

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more rice, pepper and oil

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en:
Svetlana owns a retail business that sells cosmetics and perfumes at the central market in Belaya Tserkov. She has been operating this business for 14 years. 

Svetlana started this business when her husband left. Due to her business Svetlana was able to raise her three children. Now as they have grown up and left home, she continues to help them. Svetlana’s business also grew. Today Svetlana has one employee and many loyal clients.

Svetlana would like to borrow 20,000 UAH to purchase more inventory. She hopes to increase her business's sales and receive additional income. Svetlana’s goal is to complete building a small house outside the town. She is doing the finishing work now.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetic and perfume inventory

loans.name: Nathalie

texts.fr: Née en 1973 à Porto-Novo la capitale administrative du Bénin, K. Nathalie est mariée à SOUROU Honoré, un marchand. Le couple a trois enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Il y a près de 17 ans que Nathalie s'est installée au quartier Louho Awanou dans le cinquième arrondissement de la ville de Porto-Novo. Nathalie vit dans ce quartier avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Pour faire face à ses charges, Nathalie prépare et vend des bombons, et aussi de la farine de manioc au marché de Ouando à Porto-Novo. C'est à Ikpinlè et à Ouando que Nathalie s'approvisionne. Nathalie est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de trois crédits dans l'institution, crédits qui ont été tous bien remboursés. Nathalie sollicite un quatrième prêt en vue d'élever le niveau de son activité et de mieux répondre à la demande des clients.
texts.en:
Born in 1973 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin, Ms. K. Nathalie is married to Mr. SOUROU Honoré, a merchant.  The couple have two children who are both in school.  Nearly seventeen years ago, Nathalie settled in the Louho Awanou quarter in the fifth district of the city of Porto-Novo.  She lives in this quarter with her children and husband.  The couple jointly ensure that their various family expenses are covered.  To cover her expenses, Nathalie makes and sells candy, and also cassava flour, at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo.  She gets her supplies in Ikpinlè and in Ouando.  Nathalie is a previous ALIDé client having already benefited from three loans from the micro-finance institution.  The three loans have all been repaid.  She's requesting a fourth loan for raising her business level and for responding better to customer demands.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying cassava flour and sugar for making candy

loans.name: Yusuf

texts.en:
O. is married and blessed with five children who are excelling in school. She is 40 years old and is a native of Edo State, Nigeria.

O. is into the business of tailoring and the sales of sarongs and has been in this business for fifteen years. She sews lovely Nigerian and Western styles for her customers and hopes to own a world class tailoring stall in the future. She has been able to care for her family with the proceeds of her business.

O. needs the loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more tailoring materials and sarongs to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Extract and sell gravel

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is 57 years old. Her husband is in commerce and they have four children. Her children attend school and this gives her joy.

Esther sells foodstuffs, drinks and groceries to earn a living in Benin City, Edo State. She has a good relationship with LAPO and needs a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Helena Francisco

texts.pt:
Helena Francisco N. nasceu no Distrito de Matutuine, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique, tem 40 anos de idade casada e mae de 2 filhos de 20 e 14 anos de idade, todos vão a escola. Fez somente 7ą classe, não continuou devido a casamento pré maturo. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e não sustenta mais ninguém.
Sai de Matutuine para cidade de Maputo durante a guerra de desestabilização, mais tarde constrói sua própria residência com o marido no Distrito de Boane, onde reside ate agora. Tem um negocio próprio há mais de 5 anos, não possui nenhum empregado e tem um rendimento de cerca de 6.000.00mt por mês, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária.
Já teve empréstimos no Banco CCP mais tarde decidiu não continuar devido a varias razões. Conheceu a Hluvuku através de sua vizinha que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 3º empréstimo no valor de 20.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (cerveja, refrescos, agua, sumos e outros) para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 13.000.00mt e 15.000.00mt para a mesma actividade.
 Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para ampliar o seu estabelecimento comercial.
texts.en:
Helena Francisco N. was born in the district of Matutuine, Maputo province, in southern Mozambique. She is 40 years old, married, and is the mother of two children who are 20 and 14 years old. They both go to school. She only completed the 7th grade due to her early marriage. She lives in her own house with her family and does not support anybody else. She left Matutuine for the city of Maputo during the Civil War. Later on, she built her own home with her husband in the Boane district, where she now lives. She has had her own business for over 5 years. She does not have any employees and she earns about 6,000 MZN each month, which she uses to pay for household expenses. She even saves some in her bank account. Helena has had loans before with the CCP Bank, but she later decided not to continue with them for various reasons. She found out about Hluvuku through a neighbor who is also a client of the institution. This is her third loan, which has a value of 20,000 MZN. She will use it to buy products (beer, soft drinks, water, juice, etc.) in order to increase her supply. The previous loans were for 13,000 MZN and 15,000 MZN, both for the same purpose. She promises to pay back the loan on time so she can take out other loans. In the future, she would like to request more loans to build up her business establishment.

Translated from Portuguese by Erika Korowin, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and sell products (beer, soft drinks, water, juice, etc.)

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary sells frozen fish at retail prices to her customers. She sells her frozen fish in the market in Benin City, Edo State. Mary is really itching for significant expansion in her business; she needs a loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more iced fish to sell.

Mary is 43 years old and is a hardworking woman. She is married with six children. Her children are doing well at school and this gives her joy. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more frozen fish to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more alcoholic beverage inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Build cabins to open up telephone booth service

loans.name: Ankadignonye Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe  Ankadignonyé, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 39 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Dioni, préfecture de Barouéli, Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce des condiments et de lait.
Ces femmes du groupe Ankadignonyé sont à leur deuxième prêt solidaire avec l’institution qui sera utilisé pour acheter, des paquets de condiments alimentaires et une grande quantité de lait.
Elles s’approvisionnent en condiments le plus généralement à Bamako et Barouéli et le lait est acheté dans les environs du village. Elles  effectuent leurs ventes au marché de Barouéli et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de  20 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Ankadignonyé are all married, and on average are 39 years old, have three children and all live in traditional extended families in Dioni, in the Barouéli Prefecture, part of Ségou Region (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They got acquainted through family ties and they retail food condiments and milk. The women from the Ankadignonyé group are requesting a second group loan from the institution, to buy packages of food condiments and a large quantity of milk. They generally get their condiments from Bamako and Barouéli, and the milk is purchased in the area surrounding the village. They sell their products at the Barouéli market and in area market fairs, for cash and credit, to a customer base of both men and women. They hope to reach average monthly earnings of 20,000 FCFA each, which will be used for daily family expenses, and the rest reinvested in the commercial activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy food condiments and milk

loans.name: Odete Antonio

texts.pt:
Odete António M. nasceu no Distrito de Boane, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique, tem 28 anos de idade casada e mae de 2 filhos de 9 e 3 anos de idade, o mais velho vai a escola. Fez somente 5ą classe, não continuou por motivos de doença prolongada. Vive na casa propria com a sua família e não sustenta mais ninguém.
Nunca sai de Boane, depois do casamento ergueu sua residência junto com o marido no mesmo local onde vivem ate hoje. Tem um negocio próprio há mais de 10 anos, não possui nenhum empregado e tem um rendimento de cerca de 6.000.00mt, a 7.000.00mt por mês, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum através de Xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa).
