Ja teve empréstimos no Banco CCP mais tarde decidiu não continuar devido a varias razões. Conheceu a Hluvuku através da dona Júlia Ernesto que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 4º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar (roupa de crianças diversa) para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria. Os empréstimos anteriores foram de 10.000.00mt, 13.000.00mt e 13.000.00mt para a mesma actividade.
 Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para aplicar na construção da sua residência e continuar a desenvolver o seu negócio.
texts.en:
Odete António was born in the Boane District, in the Maputo Province, South of Mozambique. She is 28 years old, married and the mother of two children who are 9 and 3 years old. The oldest is in school. She dropped out of school in the 5th grade due to a lingering illness. She lives in her own house with her family and doesn't support anyone else. She has never left Boane. After she got married, she and her husband built the house where they now live. She has had her own business for over 10 years. She doesn't have any employees and has an income of 6,000,00 to 7,000,00mt which goes to household expenses and a traditional rotational savings account (Xitique). She has had loans with CCP Bank but decided not to continue due to numerous reasons. She came to know Hluvuku through Ms. Julia Ernesto, who is also a partner of the same institution. This loan, in the amount of 15.000.00mt, is her fourth. She intends to purchase assorted pieces of children's clothing to increase her inventory. The previous loans were for 10.000.00mt, 13.000.00mt and 13.000.00mt and were all applied towards the same activity. She commits to paying this loan on time in order to be able to be granted other loans. In the future, she would like to request more loans to build her house and continue to develop her business.

Translated from Portuguese by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase and sale of assorted pieces of children's clothing

loans.name: Julie

texts.en:
Julie is a committed Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) client. LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. 

Julie sells medicines and she has been in this business for seven years. She hopes to grow her business to become stronger and bigger. She is 39 years old and married with 2 children. Her husband is a policeman and he also supports their home.

She needs a loan of 50,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more medicines to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Tete Michel

texts.en: Tete Michel K. makes and sells a local Togolese beverage called sodabi in Lomé, Togo. Sodabi is a very strong moonshine that is very popular among locals. Mr. K. has been selling this product since 2007 and is now asking for his second loan from WAGES. He will use this loan to resupply his stock of sodabi and keep his customers satisfied. Mr. K. is single and does not have children.

loans.use: Increase sodabi supplies

loans.name: Tiago Rome

texts.pt:
Tiago Rame J. nasceu Província de Tete, Centro de Moçambique, tem 53 anos de idade casado e pai de 3 filhos de 10, 2 e 1 anos de idade, o mais velho vai a escola. Fez somente 5ą classe, não continuou porque foi incorporado ao serviço militar obrigatório. Vive na casa propria com a sua família e não sustenta mais ninguém.
Sai de Tete para Boane em missão de serviço militar, depois da desmobilização continuou vivendo neste Distrito ate hoje. Ė Pensionista do Ministério da Defesa, não possui nenhum empregado e recebe 4.722.00mt de pensão por mês, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária.
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de amigo que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 1º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (cimento, pedra, areia e outros) para a construção da sua casa.
 Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para continuar com a construção da sua residência.
texts.en:
Tiago Rame J. was born in Tete Province in central Mozambique. He is 53 years old, married, and father to 3 children, ages 10, 2 and 1. The eldest child goes to school. Tiago only finished fifth grade; he did not continue with school because he was drafted for military service. He lives in his own house with his family and does not support anyone else. He left Tete for Boane to complete his military service. After demobilization, he continued living in Boane District and remains there today. He receives a pension from the Ministry of Defense. He has no employees and receives 4,722 meticais per month. He uses this money for household expenses and saves some in his bank account. Tiago has never had loans with other banks. He learned about Hluvuku through a friend who is also a customer of this institution. This is his first loan. He is asking for 15,000 meticais to buy construction materials (cement, stone, sand and other materials) in order to build his house. He promises to pay off this loan promptly so he can take out more loans. In the future, he would like to ask for more loans to continue construction on his home.

Translated from Portuguese by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of construction materials (cement, stone, sand and other materials)

loans.name: Arwo

texts.en:
Arwo R. is currently in the business of selling used clothes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock high quality clothes and sandals. Arwo is 29 and married. Her husband is a clerk, and they have two children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy sewing machines.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock high quality clothes and sandals

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 39 ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Dioni, préfecture de Barouéli, Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce de condiments alimentaires, des céréales et la préparation de galettes.
Ces femmes du groupe Benkadi viennent de commencer leur collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont leur premier prêt.
Ce  premier prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, une grande quantité  de condiments alimentaires de différentes sortes et des sacs de céréales pour en faire des galettes.
Elles s’approvisionnent en condiments alimentaires et en céréales à Barouéli  et environnants. Elles  effectuent leurs ventes au marché de Barouéli  et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15 000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Benkadi group are all married, and on average are 39 years old, have two children and all live in traditional extended families in Dioni, in the Barouéli Prefecture, part of Ségou Region (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They got acquainted through family ties and they retail food condiments and grain cereals, and prepare flatcakes.. The women from the Benkadi group have just begun collaborating with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI and are requesting a first group loan. The loan will be used to buy a large quantity of various food condiments and bags of cereals to make flatcakes. They generally get their condiments and cereals from Barouéli and the surrounding area. They sell their products at the Barouéli market and in area market fairs, for cash, retail and credit, to a customer base of both men and women. They hope to reach average monthly earnings of 15,000 FCFA each, which will be used for daily family expenses, and the rest reinvested in the commercial activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy food condiments and cereals

loans.name: Zahida's Group

texts.en:
Sardaran wants a loan to buy leather to resell. Reeta Hadayat wants a loan to buy repairing tools for her motor workshop. Fazilat wants a loan to buy seasonal fruit to resell. Zubaida wants a loan to buy seasonal vegetables to resell. Zahida is the group leader of the afore-mentioned ladies. They all live in a city named Lahore, famous in Pakistan for its historical places and its Punjabi foods. 

Zahida has given birth to three girls and one boy. Her eldest daughter is 20 years old and she completed her education till 10th standard. The other two are enrolled in a school and are getting an education. Her son has a food stand in the market where he sells specifically “Dahi Bhalay” which is in high demand.  

Zahida herself runs a beauty salon. She reserves one room of her house for it. Her eldest daughter also helps her to take care of the customers. She saves her income for her daughters’ marriage. 

Zahida is applying for a loan to buy items (yogurt, potatoes, and cooking oil) to expand her son's food business.

loans.use: To buy items for food-selling business

loans.name: Anabela Daniel

texts.pt:
Anabela Daniel M. nasceu na cidade de Maputo, Província do mesmo nome, sul de Moçambique, tem 34 anos de idade viuva e mae de 4 filhos de 11, 08, 06 e 04 anos de idade, os 3 mais velhos vão a escola. Fez somente 10ą classe, parou quando perdeu seu marido. Vive na casa própria com os seus filhos e não sustenta mais ninguém.
Sai de Maputo para a cidade da Matola quando contraiu o matrimónio, onde juntamente com seu falecido esposo fixara sua residência. Tem um negocio próprio há mais de 11 anos, não possui nenhum empregado e vende mais refrescos onde consegue um rendimento de cerca de 5.500.00mt por mês, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum com as amigas através de Xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa).
Já teve empréstimos na cooperativa de crédito TCHUMA mais tarde decidiu na continuar por vários motivos. Conheceu a Hluvuku através de sua vizinha que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 3º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (ovos, óleo, arroz, amendoim e outros) para aumentar a quantidade e diversificar ainda mais a sua mercadoria.
 Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para continuar com a construção da sua obra para posteriormente a rendar.
texts.en:
Anabela Daniel M. was born in the city of Maputo, Maputo Province in southern Mozambique. She is 34 years old, widowed, and mother to four children, ages 11, 8, 6, and 4. The three eldest go to school. Anabela only finished tenth grade; she quit when she lost her husband. She lives in her own house with her children and does not support anyone else. When she got married, Anabela left Maputo for the city of Matola, where she established residence together with her late husband. She has had her own business for more than 11 years. She has no employees and sells mainly soft drinks. Her monthly income is about 5,500 meticais, which she uses for household expenses. She also saves some money with friends through Xitique (a traditional system of rotating savings). Anabela has taken out loans before with the Tchuma Credit Association. She decided not to continue with them for several reasons. She learned about Hluvuku from a neighbor who is also a customer at this institution. This is her third loan. She is asking for 15,000 meticais, which she will use to buy products (eggs, oil, rice, peanuts and other products) to increase and diversify her inventory. She promises to pay off this loan on time so she can take out more loans. In the future, she would like to ask for more loans to continue construction on a rental house.

Translated from Portuguese by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase and sale of products (eggs, oil, peanuts and other products)

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary L. is currently in the business of selling bedsheets at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bedsheets, dresses, pairs of trousers to sell. Mary is 28 years old and married. She and her husband, a business man, have 3 children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a hotel.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bedsheets, dresses, pairs of trousers to sell

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Danaya, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 42 ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Siemana, préfecture de Barouéli, Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce d’habillements, de condiments alimentaire et d’argile blanche.
Après avoir correctement remboursés les quatre prêts précédents, ces femmes du groupe Danaya sont à leur cinquième prêt solidaire avec l’institution qui sera utilisé pour acheter, des colis de condiments alimentaires, des sacs d’argile et des habillements pour enfant et femmes.           .
Elles s’approvisionnent plus généralement à Barouéli  et Konobougou. Elles  effectuent leurs ventes au marché de Siemana, Barouéli et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 25.000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Danaya group are all married, and on average are 42 years old, have two children and all live in traditional extended families in the village of Siemana, in the Barouéli Prefecture, part of Ségou Region (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They got acquainted through family ties and they retail clothing, food condiments and white clay. Having correctly reimbursed all four preceding loans, the women of the Danaya group are requesting a fifth group loan from the institution. The loan will be used to buy packages of food condiments, bags of clay, and clothing for children and women. They generally get their supplies from Barouéli and Konobougou. They sell their products at the Siemana market, in Barouéli and in area market fairs, for cash, retail and credit, to a customer base of both men and women. They hope to reach average monthly earnings of 25,000 FCFA each, which will be used for daily family expenses, and the rest reinvested in the commercial activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various products

loans.name: Maqsoodan's Group

texts.en:
Maqsoodan is a very active lady. She operates a clothes-selling business in the community. Her clientele base is her neighbors. Once a month she goes to various bazaars of Lahore, especially “Ichra & Azam market,” for purchasing new clothes. Her income allows her to share the financial burden of her husband. Her husband's name is J. M. and he works in a factory at a meager income. She is applying for a loan to buy seasonal clothes to expand her clothes-selling business and to fill the orders from her customers.

She has four other ladies in her loan group. Zahida wants a loan to buy items such as cosmetics and a hair dryer for her beauty salon. Parveen wants a loan to buy scrap for her scrap business. Another Parveen wants a loan to buy a sewing machine for her sewing clothes business. Nazir begum wants a loan to buy a dairy cow for her dairy business.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Vadim

texts.en:
Vadim is 19 years old. He sells music CD's and tapes as well as some games and toys. He rents a space in the central department store at Vasilievka town.

Vadim started this business about a year ago. He just saw that there was a high demand and low supply of this kind of inventory at this store, so he decided to try. He started this business and it began to grow.

Vadim is very enthusiastic about further development of his business. He would like to borrow 9,600 UAH to purchase more inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Our God Is Able Group

texts.en: Tenneh V. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called “Our God Is Able”. She is 40 years old, single, and has three children who range from 8 to 17 years old. Tenneh could not continue her education through 7th grade due to lack of financial support. In the photo, Tenneh is the one holding the sign. For five years, Tenneh has been selling foodstuffs such as rice, sugar and peanuts at the VOA Junction in Northern Monrovia, Liberia. She encourages her customers to continue to come and buy from her, which keeps them returning. Tenneh plans to use her 8,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 40,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more rice, sugar and peanuts. Her goal is to grow her business to a shop and help her children have a good future. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more rice, sugar and peanuts to sell

loans.name: Akossiwa

texts.en:
Akossiwa H. is married and has three children. She has been selling charcoal in Lomé, Togo, since 2004. Her product is a necessity among many Togolese households, which ensures that her demand remains high. 

She is now asking for her first loan from Kiva partner WAGES, which she will use to resupply her stock. With this loan, Mrs. H.’s personal life and professional life will benefit.

loans.use: Purchase of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Guilhermina Francisco

texts.pt:
Guilhermina Francisco D. nasceu na cidade de Xai xai, Província de Gaza, sul de Moçambique, tem 47 anos de idade casada e mae de 4 filhos de 30, 27, 24 e 16 anos de idade, destes 2 vão a escola. Fez somente 7ą classe, parou quando o seu nome saiu para ir a antiga Republica Democrática da Alemanha. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e sustenta 2 netos que vivem com ela.
Sai de Xai xai para a cidade da Matola com o seu marido depois de seu casamento, onde juntamente com seu esposo fixaram sua residência. Tem um negocio próprio há mais de 17 anos, possui um empregado que lhe auxilia no seu negocio. Vende mais maçã, onde consegue um rendimento de cerca de 3.500.00mt por mês, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária do BARCLAYS.
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de um familiar que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 1º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar produtos (maçãs, bolos, refrescos, banana e outros) para aumentar a quantidade e diversificar ainda mais a sua mercadoria.
 Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para remodelar a sua residência.
texts.en:
Guilhermina Francisco D. was born in Xai Xai, Gaza Province, south of Mozambique. She is 47, married and the mother of 4 children ages 30, 27, 24 and 16, two of them students. She dropped school on 7th grade. She lives in her own house with her family and supports two grandchildren that live with her. She left Xai Xai to go to Matola with her husband after they got married. She's owned her own business for the past 17 years and has an employee that helps her. Her best selling product are the apples, and she makes around U$100 per month which she uses to support her household and save some in the bank. She never took loans in other banks and she heard of Hluvuku through a relative that's also a client. This is her first loan and she's asking for U$475, which she'll use to buy more merchandise (apples, pastries, beverages, bananas and others) to diversify her business and attract more clients. She is committed to pay the loan on time to take others in the future, as she dreams of remodeling her house.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of food and beverages for reselling

loans.name: Abdel-Rahman

texts.en:
Abdel-Rahman has owned a fishing boat since 2000. He is an experienced fisherman; he has been working for over forty years.

With his first loan of US $1,000 from Kiva lenders, Abdel-Rahman was able to repair his boat. He’s pleased with his decision to take a loan from Ameen. He has been very reliable with his repayments and has actually repaid his loan in full severA. months early.

Today, Abdel-Rahman is requesting a larger loan of $2,000 to carry out maintenance work on his boat to increase its safety features. In the future, he would like to purchase a bigger and more technically advanced boat so that he can expand his business even more.

loans.use: To carry out maintenance work on his boat

loans.name: Diki

texts.en:
Diki M. is currently in the business of selling sugar, salts, etc., in a retail shop. She is requesting a loan to stock boxes of soap, biscuits, etc., to sell. Diki is 39 years old and married to a nurse. She has six children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.

In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted toward returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock boxes of soap, biscuits, etc., to sell

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Les sept  femmes du groupe Danaya sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 40 ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de  Dioni, préfecture de Barouéli, Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce de condiments.
Ces femmes sont à leur première expérience Soro Yiriwaso.
Elle compte utiliser leur prêt  pour acheter, des paquets de différentes sortes de condiments alimentaires.
Elles s’approvisionnent à Barouéli  et Konobougou auprès des grossistes et producteurs et effectuent leurs ventes au marché de Barouéli, Konobougou, dans les foires environnantes et sur place à Dioni, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 25.000FCFA  qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The seven women of the Danaya group are all married, and on average are 40 years old, have two children and all live in traditional extended families in the village of Dioni, in the Barouéli Prefecture, part of Ségou Region (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They got acquainted through family ties and they retail food condiments. These women are experiencing their first credit loan with Soro Yiriwaso. The loan will be used to buy packages of various types of food condiments. They get their supplies from wholesalers and producers in Barouéli and Konobougou. They sell their products at the Barouéli and Konobougou markets, at market fairs in the area and locally in Dioni, for cash, retail and on credit, to a customer base of both men and women. They hope to reach average monthly earnings of 25,000 FCFA each, which will be used for daily family expenses, and the rest reinvested in the commercial activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy food condiments

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more phone charge cards

loans.name: Lizar

texts.en:
Lizar J. is 28 years old and married to a businessman. They have two children who go to school. Lizar sells charcoal and groundnut paste at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell. With the extra profits her loan will bring in, she hopes to be able to open a charcoal store.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Sergio Pedro

texts.pt:
Sérgio Pedro W. nasceu no Distrito de Massinga, Província de Inhambane, sul de Moçambique, tem 25 anos de idade casado e pai de 2 filhos de 5 anos e 6 meses de idade, ainda não vão a escola. Fez 10ą classe, não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e não sustenta mais ninguém.
Sai de Inhambane para o Distrito de Namaacha com os seus pais devido a Guerra de desestabilização. Mais tarde iniciou seu próprio lar e seu próprio negoceia, possui 2 parcelas de agricultura que usa para produzir hortícolas para venda. Consegue um rendimento de cerca 2.000.00mt por mês, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária.
Nunca teve emprestimos em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de vizinho que também é cliente desta instituição. Este é o seu 1º empréstimo no valor de 15.000.00mt com o qual pretende comprar material de construção (portas, janelas, cimento e outros).  
 Compromete se a pagar devidamente este empréstimo para poder aceder a outros. No futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para continuar com a construção da sua residência e ampliar as suas áreas de cultivo.
texts.en:
Sérgio Pedro W. was born in Massinga, Inhambane Province, south of Mozambique. He is 25 years old, married and the father of two children aged 5 and 6 months, neither one of them go to school yet. He dropped school on 10th grade due to lack of financial support. He lives in his own house and doesn't support anyone else besides his family. He left Inhambane to the Namaacha District with his parents during the War of Destabilization. Later on he build his house and started his business. He owns some land that he uses to plant vegetables to sell. He makes around U$80 per month and uses the money to support his household and save some in a bank account. He never tood loans in other banks and heard of Hluvuku through a neighbor that's also a client. This is Sergio's first loan and he's asking for U$475 to buy construction supplies (doors, windows, cement and others). He is committed to pay the loan back on time so he can take other loans in the future, in order to keep improving his house and his business.

Translated from Portuguese by Mariana Dauwe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction Supplies

loans.name: Djekafo Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djekafo sont toutes mariées. Elles ont en moyenne 26 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Siemana, préfecture de Barouéli, Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce de nourriture, d’argile et d’articles divers.
Ces femmes du groupe Djekafo sont à leur cinquième prêt solidaire avec l’institution, après avoir bien remboursés les quatre précédents.
Ce nouveau prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter, des sacs de riz, une importante quantité d’articles divers et  des sacs d’argiles blanches.
L’approvisionnent en marchandises se fait  à Barouéli et à Konobougou auprès des grossistes et producteurs. Elles effectuent leurs ventes au marché de Barouéli et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 30.000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The seven women of the Djekafo group are all married, and on average are 26 years old, have three children and all live in traditional extended families in the village of Dioni, in the Siemana Prefecture, part of Ségou Region (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They got acquainted through family ties and they retail food, clay and various items. These women from the Djekafo group are requesting their fifth group loan with the institution, having repaid in full the four preceding loans. This new loan will be used to buy bags of rice, a large quantity of various items and bags of white clay. They get their supplies from wholesalers and producers in Barouéli and Konobougou. They sell their products at the Barouéli market, and at market fairs in the area, for cash, retail and on credit, to a customer base of both men and women. They hope to reach average monthly earnings of 30,000 FCFA each, which will be used for daily family expenses, and the rest reinvested in the commercial activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various items

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 29 years old; she is single and resides in Lagos State, Nigeria. She owns a salon at the front of her house where she styles people’s hair and sells hair accessories like hair extensions, cream and more to make a living. She loves doing this business as it gives her the opportunity to interact with other people from different backgrounds. Customers patronize her because of the good service she renders to them. The person appearing in the picture is one of her customers.

Elizabeth has been in the salon business for five years and she wants a loan of 70,000 nairas to purchase more hair extensions and hair cream to sell and make more profit. With this business, she assists her siblings in meeting some of their financial needs. She promises to repay her loan by the due date. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for the financial assistance.

loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions and hair cream to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more medicine.

loans.name: Maya

texts.en:
Maya is a 27-year-old married woman. In order to help with her family’s expenses, Maya has opened a beauty salon in her home. She has taken a first loan of $1,000 and she was able to expand her home business by adding new services and purchasing more equipment. Maya says that her business productivity and income have both increased as a result of this loan. She has also been able to attract new clients. Over the course of her loan term, Maya has consistently paid on time and she has even repaid the full loan amount earlier than her scheduled end date. 

Today, she is asking for a loan of $2,000 to prepare a big beauty room with all the arrangements needed. In the future, Maya would like to open a formal beauty salon for women. She is working to achieve even greater business success in the coming year.

loans.use: To prepare a big beauty room

loans.name: Djiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djiguisseme, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 43 ans, 2 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Dioni, préfecture de Barouéli, Région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce de condiments  alimentaires et de la restauration.
Ces femmes du groupe  Djiguisseme viennent de commencer leur collaboration  avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur premier prêt solidaire.
Ce premier prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, des paquets de différentes variétés de condiments alimentaires et des sacs de céréales pour la préparation des plats alimentaires.
Elles s’approvisionnent en condiments et céréales à Barouéli, Konobougou et dans les villages environnants. Elles  effectuent leurs ventes sur place, au marché de Barouéli et dans les foires environnantes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 20.000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Djiguisseme group are all married, and on average are 43 years old, have two children and all live in traditional extended families in the village of Dioni, in the Barouéli Prefecture, part of Ségou Region (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They got acquainted through family ties and they retail food condiments and food preparations. The women from the Djiguisseme group have just started their collaboration with the Soro Yiriwaso MFI and are requesting their first group loan.. This first loan will be used to buy packages of various types of food condiments and bags of cereal to prepare food. They get condiments and cereals from Barouéli, Konobougou and villages in the area. They sell their products locally, at the Barouéli market, and at market fairs in the area, for cash, retail and on credit, to a customer base of both men and women. They hope to reach average monthly earnings of 20,000 FCFA each, which will be used for daily family expenses, and the rest reinvested in the commercial activities.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy ingredients for food preparations

loans.name: Djiguisseme Group

texts.fr:
Les femmes du groupe Djiguisseme, toutes mariées, ont en moyenne 29 ans, 3 enfants et vivent toutes dans des familles traditionnelles élargies à Konobougou, sous préfecture de Barouéli, région de Ségou (quatrième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté et font le commerce d’habillements, de condiments et d’articles divers.
Ces femmes du groupe  Djiguisseme sont leur prêt avec Soro Yiriwaso qui sera utilisé pour acheter, des paquets de condiments alimentaires, des habillements et des articles divers.
Elles s’approvisionnent en habillements au Burkina, en condiments et articles divers à Konobougou et environnants. Elles  effectuent leurs ventes au marché de Konobougou et à Bamako, au comptant, en détail et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 35.000FCFA qui sera utilisé  dans les dépenses  quotidiennes de la famille et le reste sera  réinvesti dans les activités de commerce.
texts.en:
The women of the Djiguisseme Group, all married, are on average 29 years old and have 3 children. They all live in traditional extended families in Konobougou, a sub-prefecture of Barouéli in the Ségou region (fourth administrative district in the Republic of Mali). They met through family connections and sell clothing, spices and miscellaneous goods. These women of the Djiguisseme Group *are requesting their loan with from Soro Yiriwaso* which will be used to buy packages of edible spices, clothing and miscellaneous goods. They get their clothing supplies in Burkina Faso, and their spices and other goods in or near Konobougou. They conduct their sales in the Konobougou and Bamako markets, for cash, *retail* and credit, to a client base made up of both women and men. They expect to achieve an average monthly profit of XOF 35,000 each, which will be used for the daily expenses of the family. The rest will be reinvested in the business.

Translated from French by Jessalyn Pinneo, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying clothing, spices and miscellaneous goods.

loans.name: Madeleine

texts.fr: Née en 1977 à Savalou dans le département des Collines au Bénin, L. Madeleine est mariée à DOHOU Stéphane, un informaticien. Le couple a trois enfants dont certains sont scolarisés. Madeleine vit depuis sept ans au quartier Djassin dans le troisième arrondissement de la ville de Porto-Novo, avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges familiales. Madeleine n'a pas féquenté l'école. Pour assurer ses différentes charges, Madeleine fabrique et vend des sucettes qu'elle conserve dans un réfrigérateur. De façon secondaire, Madeleine vend également des chaussures et des sacs de façon ambulante. Madeleine s'approvisionne à Lomé au Togo, Etat voisin du Bénin. Madeleine exerce cette activité depuis six ans et à déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé. Les crédits ont été tous bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Madeleine sollicite un troisième crédit, en vue de renforcer surtout son activité de vente de chaussures et de sacs, afin de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Born in 1977 in Savalou in the Collines Department of Benin, Madeleine L. is married to Stéphane DOHOU, a computer specialist. They have three children, of whom some attend school. Madeleine settled some seven years ago in the Djassin neighborhood in the third borough of Porto-Novo, where she lives with her husband and children. The couple share family expenses. Madeleine has not attended school. To meet her financial responsibilities Madeleine makes and sells ice pops that she keeps in a freezer. As a secondary activity, she also sells shoes and handbags as an itinerant vendor. She gets supplies from Lomé in Togo, a neighboring country. Madeleine has been in business for the past six years and has already been granted two loans from ALIDé, both fully reimbursed. Given the increasing customer demand, Madeleine is requesting a third loan, particularly to bolster her sales of shoes and handbags and improve customer satisfaction.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy sugar and plastic bags to make ice pops, and shoes.

loans.name: Palmier Plus Group

texts.en:
Jean Jacques N. is the leader of the 37-member group named “Palmier Plus” which means “Palm tree” in English. The group has formed in order to apply for  Kiva loans with the goal of developing their businesses.

Jean Jacques has been part of the micro-enterprise world since 1996. He runs a drugstore in the west of Kinshasa and has acquired solid experience in this area. He works hard with good management skills in order to realize his dream of one day opening a large drugstore in his community. He would also like to achieve financial independence through his business that currently earns him $200 per month. He works to the best of his abilities and uses his contacts to achieve his goals. Mike is a trustworthy client of the MFI HOPE RDC, having received and correctly repaid four loans. He will increase his stock of medicines with his next loan, re-selling them at a profit. Jean Jacques is 39 and married with six children, two of them in school.

loans.use: increasing the drugstore’s stock by buying medicines reselling them at profit.

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Bunmi

texts.en:
Bunmi is a member of LAPO microfinance with a good repayment record. She owns a boutique where she sells ladies shoes, bags and clothes to customers. She has been in the business for about 20 years now. She uses part of the proceeds from her trade to help her husband in sponsoring the children’s education and feeding, and reinvests the other part into the business. 

Bunmi is very determined and wants to expand the size of her business to have an additional shop where she can sell ladies shoes, bags and clothes and make more profit. She hopes for a loan of 100,000 nairas to purchase more ladies shoes, bags and clothes to sell.
 
Bunmi is 39 years old and married with two children. They live in Lagos, Nigeria. She appreciates Kiva lenders for this initiative.

loans.use: To purchase more ladies shoes, bags and clothes to sell

loans.name: Magdalene

texts.en: Magdalene is 35 years old, married and has 2 children. Her husband is a mechanical engineer. Magdalene is a LAPO client; she has been with LAPO for 4 years. She owns a grocery store where she sells groceries and drinks at retail prices. Magdalene is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Raïssa

texts.fr: Née en 1985 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin, A. Raïssa réside au quartier Koutongbé à Porto-Novo, depuis son jeune âge. C'est une célibataire sans enfant. Raïssa vit donc seule et assure seule ses différentes charges. Raïssa n'a fréquenté que l'école primaire. Il y a près de 10 ans, afin de  subvenir à ses besoins, Raïssa vend des sachets et des tenues de sport à son domicile et aussi de façon ambulante. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Raïssa s'approvisionne. Raïssa a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. Raïssa voudrait agrandir son étalage et mieux faire face aux différentes demandes des clients. Pour y arriver, Raïssa sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé,afin d'augmenter son fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
Born in 1985 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin, Raïssa A. lived in the Koutongbé neighborhood of Porto-Novo since an early age. She is unmarried without children, lives alone and is the only provider for her various needs. She attended school at primary level only. For the past ten years Raïssa has supported herself by selling plastic bags and sportswear from her home and also as an itinerant vendor. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin’s international market. Raïssa has already been granted two previous loans from ALIDé, both of which were correctly repaid. She would like to expand her shop display and improve her response to various customer demands. To achieve this she is requesting a third loan from ALIDé to increase her working capital.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy sportswear and plastc bags

loans.name: Bukky

texts.en:
Bukky is self employed; she manages a tailoring business. She employs staff to assist her in offering a quality service. She makes clothes of different styles and sells material to make more profit. She is a member of LAPO microfinance and has a good record.
She needs more income from this trade to support her husband in sponsoring their children’s education and to meet other needs.

Bukky is very determined and wants to expand the size of her business. She hopes for a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more material to sell to increase her profits.  
 
Bukky is 32 years old, married with three children and lives in Lagos Nigeria. She says thanks to Kiva LAPO microfinance for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring material to sell.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Stella is a fashion designer. She also sells tailoring materials. She specializes in making female clothes and has been in this business for 5 years. She is the young mother of one child. She is 27 years old and is married to a commercial driver. Stella hopes to acquire a more sophisticated, industrial sewing machine to boost her business. She also hopes to add the sale of cosmetics to her business. She hopes to have more children and to give them the basic necessities of life. She needs a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more tailoring materials and an industrial sewing machine to boost her fashion business.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials and an industrial sewing machine

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en: Roseline is 58 years old, married with 6 children. She owns a store where she sells drinks and bottled water at wholesale and retail prices. Her husband sells building materials to support their household. Roseline has been in this business for 31 years. She is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She hopes to expand her business. She appreciates all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Aurore Plus Group

texts.en:
Aurore Plus is a Community Bank made up of 24 members all united for the same goal: to grow their businesses by loans received from Kiva through IMF HOPE RDC.

The members' chairwoman is Jiji, who runs a general store and sells used clothing. She began her business in 1992. After hard work and good management, she succeeded in making it thrive thanks to the accumulated profits. She intends to expand it with the next loan by adding pieces of fabric and replenishing the store’s stock by buying cans, soaps, sugar, beans, rice, etc. The business gives her a profit of $250.00 every month. Jiji is 41 years old, married and the mother of 7 children, whose ages vary between 3 and 20 years old. Five of them attend school.

loans.use: increasing the store’s stock of used clothing and reselling them at profit

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Chérifath

texts.fr: M. Chérifath est née le 22 Novembre 1962 et vit depuis huit ans au quartier Sèdjèko, dans le deuxième arrondissement de la ville de Porto-Novo. Chérifath est mère de trois enfants qui vivent tous avec elle. Mais seulement certains enfants sont scolarisés. Chérifath ne vit plus avec son mari. Chérifath  assure donc seule les différentes charges de la famille. Chérifath n'a fait que l'école primaire. Il y a près de 20 ans que Chérifath mène comme activité, la vente de l'encens à Porto-Novo. Chérifath s'approvisionne au Ghana, Etat voisin du Bénin. Chérifath a obtenu une fois déjà de crédit auprès de ALIDé, crédit qui a été bien remboursé. Chérifath sollicite un deuxième crédit, afin d'augmenter le stock de ses produits et d'agrandir son activité pour se faire plus de revenu. Chérifath ambitionne plus tard construire sa propre maison.
texts.en:
Chérifath M. was born November 22nd 1962 and has been living for eight years in Sèdjèko, an area of the 12th district of the city of Porto-Novo. Chérifath is mother of three children who all live with her. But not the three of them are attending school. Chérifath does not live anymore with her husband, so that she has to take care by herself of the family expenses. She attended only primary school. For about twenty years she has been selling incense in Porto-Novo. She purchases her supplies in Ghana, a neighbor country. Chérifath already received a loan from ALIDé, and she fully repaid it. Now she is requesting a second loan in order to increase the stock of her products and expand her business to make more revenue. In the future Chérifath hopes to build her own house.

Translated from French by MONICA URBAN, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of incense

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith is a trader and she sells groceries, kerosene and foodstuffs such as rice, beans, garri (cassava flakes), soaps, milk and cooking oil. She started this business 4 years ago and she is doing well. 

She is 44 years old, married with 6 children. Her husband is a musician and he also supports their household. She hopes to see her business grow bigger and stronger. She needs a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more groceries and kerosene to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and kerosene to  sell

loans.name: Sefinat

texts.en:
Sefinat owns a shop where she sells drinks and groceries at retail prices. She wants to expand and improve on her business so as to increase her profits and save for the future.
Sefinat is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more drinks to sell to meet customer demand. This will increase profits and let her expand and improve her business and assist her family.

She is 32 years old, married and blessed with two children. They all live in Lagos state, Nigeria. She says thanks to all lenders for their financial support.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace is 48 years old; she is married with 6 children. Her children are doing well in school and this makes her happy. Her husband is a farmer. She sells goats in the market. She has been in this business for 11 years. Grace hopes to improve her family’s standard of living. Grace is requesting a loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more goats to sell. Grace says thanks.

loans.use: To purchase more goats to sell

loans.name: Rachidatou

texts.fr: Née en 1970 à Djigbé dans le département de l'Ouémé au Bénin où elle vit depuis sa naissance, A. Rachidatou est mariée à GLOGJINON Thomas, un chauffeur. Le couple a cinq enfants, mais trois sont à leurs charges. Certains des enfants sont scolarisés. Rachidatou vient en aide à son mari et assure avec elle les différentes charges de la famille. Rachidatou n'a jamais été à l'école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et assurer les besoins de ses enfants, Rachidatou fabrique et vend des gâteaux (faits à base de manioc et d'huile de palme) à son domicile. Rachidatou s'approvisionne à Hozin dans l'Ouémé au Bénin. Rachidatou exerce cette activité depuis 10 ans et a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé. Rachidatou  a bien remboursé les crédits. Rachidatou voudrait augmenter le volume de son activité et augmenter son chiffre d'affaire. C'est donc pour renforcer son activité et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle que Rachidatou sollicite un troisième prêt de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Born in 1970 in Djibé in the Ouémé region of Bénin where she has lived since birth, Rachidatou A. is married to Thomas Glogjinon, a chauffeur. The couple has five children, three of whom are now under their care. Some of their children went to school. Rachidatou helps her husband and takes on different family responsibilities. Rachidatou never went to school. To meet her and her children's needs, Rachidatou makes and sells cakes (made from a cassava and palm oil base) from her home. She stocks up on supplies in Hozin in Ouémé, Bénin. Rachidatou has done this work for ten years and has already received two loans from ALIDé. She repaid these loans in full. Rachidatou would like to increase her amount of work and her sales. Rachidatou is thus asking for a third loan from ALIDé in order to strengthen her business and better satisfy her clientele.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cassava and palm oil

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience is 48 years old; she is married with 4 children. Her children are doing well in school and this makes her happy. Her husband sells building materials. She sells goats in the market. She has been in this business for 9 years. Patience hopes to improve her family’s standard of living. She is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more goats to sell. Patience says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more goats to sell

loans.name: Rolande Kaolo

texts.en: Rolande Kaolo A. is a trained hairdresser. She lives and works in Lomé, Togo and is married with three children. Mrs. A. now runs a bar called "Snack Bar Kingdom,” a business she began in 2001. This will be her third loan with WAGES, and she will use it to resupply her stock of beers and soft drinks. This loan will help keep Mrs. A.’s customers hydrated and satisfied.

loans.use: Purchase of alcohol and soft drinks

loans.name: Kuyange

texts.en:
Kuyange M. is currently in the business of selling food at a restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more rice and beans to cook and sell.  Kuyange is 32 years old and is married with a husband who is a peasant. She has 4 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her restaurant.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more rice and beans to cook and sell

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca is married with four children. She is 36 years old. Her husband is a businessman and he also supports their family. Rebecca is a trader; she sells groceries, drinks and cooking oil. She has been running this business for 5 years. Rebecca needs a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She says a big thank-you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to sell

loans.name: Moyo

texts.en: Moyo L. is currently in the business of selling various items at her retail shop and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of sugar and salt to sell. Moyo is 45 years old and is widowed. She has nine children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a hotel (restaurant). About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more bags of sugar and salt to sell

loans.name: Léontine

texts.fr: A. Léontine est née en 1960 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à HOLOGAN Etienne, Léontine est mère de quatre enfants qui sont tous scolarisés. Mais Léontine vit seulement avec deux des enfants. La famille s'est installée au quartier Avakpa dans le troisième arrondissement de la ville de Porto-Novo, depuis cinq ans. Le couple supporte ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Léontine n'a pas été à l'école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins, Léontine vend de la nourriture (ignames frits, gâteaux de haricot et bananes frites) à Porto-Novo. Léontine s'approvisionne au marché de Ouando à Porto-Novo. Léontine a déjà obtenu deux crédits de ALIDé, et les a tous bien remboursés. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de sa clientèle, Léontine sollicite un troisième prêt de ALIDé, en vue d'augmenter son stock de produits et de mieux faire face à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Léontine A. was born in 1960 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin. Married to Etienne Hologan, Léontine is the mother of four children who are all educated. But Léontine only lives with two of her children. The family has lived in the Avakpa quarter, in Novo-Porto's third district, for five years. Together, the couple takes on the family's various responsibilities. Léontine did not go to school. To meet her needs, she sells food (fried yams, fried bean and banana cakes) in Porto-Novo. Léontine gets her supplies at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo. Léontine has already received two loans from ALIDé which she has repaid in full. Faced with increased demand from her ever-growing clientele, she is asking for a third loan from ALIDé. Léontine would like to increase her stock of products and better meet the demand of her clients.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of bananas and yams

loans.name: Miata Group

texts.en: Miata F. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Miata Group. She is 40 years old, single, and has three children who range from 9 months to 18 years old. She did not have the opportunity to go school. For five years, Miata has been selling used clothes at the #7 Community Market in Margibi County, Liberia. She sells high-quality used clothes, which keeps customers returning. Miata plans to use her 4,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 20,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more used clothes. Her goal is to grow her business to a store and to give her children higher education so that they can have a better future. In the photo, Miata is the one holding the sign. Larry G. is inset at the lower right. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes to sell

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is the 30-year-old mother of two children aged 14 and 9 years. She is married and lives with five people in her home. Her main focus for the family is to see her children get a good education.

Monica has a canteen which she operates in a high school called Duhaga Secondary School and has been in business for ten years. She started with a wooden canteen selling only small quantities of stationery like books and pens but with the help of credit from HOFOKAM she has been able to set up a metal canteen with all the requirements of students including foods which have the biggest demand.

Monica hopes with future credit and profits from the business to enlarge the size of her canteen. She will the loan to buy a container for a canteen business at another school.

loans.use: To buy a container for a canteen business at another school

loans.name: Helen

texts.en: Helen is 40 years old, married with 4 children. She owns a grocery store where she sells groceries and drinks. Her husband also works to support their household. She is a LAPO client. Helen says her expectations are to grow her business and to be able to provide her children with the basic needs of life. She is requesting a loan of NGN 80,000 to purchase more groceries and drinks to sell. She says a big thank-you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries and drinks to  sell

loans.name: God Is Good Group

texts.en: For 7 years, John K. has been selling palm oil at the Kingsville #7 Community, which is located near Monrovia, Liberia. He is 56 years old, married and has three children who range in age from 20 to 29 years old. He is friendly with his customers which keeps them returning. John plans to use his 8,000 Liberian dollar (LRD) portion of this 40,000 LRD group loan to buy more palm oil. His goal is to grow his business and to continue to support his children by giving them good medical attention. John is the leader of this group of five borrowers called "God Is Good". In the photo that accompanies this profile, John is the one holding the sign. Joseph T. is in the inset at the lower right. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, this non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more palm oil

loans.name: Janty

texts.en:
Janty F. is currently in the business of baking and selling local Sudanese bread cooked by frying in oil and is requesting a loan to stock more baking flour. She is 31 years old and married to a soldier. She has three children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to purchase more cooking oil in order to expand her business.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services. The programs are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more baking flour

loans.name: Cité De La Gloire Plus Group

texts.en:
Huguettes’s main business is selling vegetables in a market to the west of Kinshasa. She earns $480 per month. Since 1994, she has acquired solid experience in this area and works hard with good management skills in order to realize her dream of one day becoming a vegetable provider in her community. She would also like to achieve financial independence through her business. She works to the best of her abilities and uses her contacts so that she might achieve her goals. 

Huguettes is a trustworthy client of the MFI (Micro-Finance Institution) HOPE RDC, having five times obtained and correctly repaid loans. She will increase her stock of products with her next loan by buying vegetables and reselling them at a profit.

Huguettes is the director of the group “Cité de la Gloire Plus” made up of 26 members firmly united to receive loans from the MFI HOPE RDC in order to develop their businesses.

loans.use: To increase the inventory of her business in order to reinforce the working capital

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Paraguay Renda Group

texts.es:
Este Comité se formo a través de la Sra. Romelia B., quien se entero del programa por medio de su hermana quien es integrante de otro comite y comentó sobre las cosas positivas obtenidad mediante la conformación del comite de mujeres emprendoras, teniendo en cuenta esto, ella invito a sus amigas y compañeras del Barrio y desidieron sumarse al trabajo grupal para salir adelante y así mejorar su estilo de vida, son 24(Veinte y Cuatro) mujeres trabajadoras y humildes quienes deben trabjar muy duro para ganarse el sustento todos los dias, y así llevar adelante a sus familias.
La Sra. Romelia, teniendo en cuental la gran demanda por inicio de temporada y de clases, adquierirá con el préstamos solicitado; mercaderías como útiles escolares(cuaderno, mochilas, cartucheras, lapeces, carpetas archivadoras, tipos de hojas) y de oficina, así como accesorios para uniformes de colegios y otros para aumentar el stock de la tienda que ella posee.
texts.en:
This group formed because of Romelia B.. She found out about the program through her sister, a member of another group. Her sister told her about the positive things she has gotten by the formation of the group of enterprising women. Keeping this in mind, she invited her friends and colleagues from the neighborhood. They decided to join the group work in order to get ahead and improve their lifestyle. They are 24 hard-working and humble women who work very hard to win their sustenance every day. That way they get their families ahead. Keeping in mind the great demand there is at the start of the season and the classes, Romelia will use the requested loan to buy merchandise. She will buy things like school and office supplies (notebooks, backpacks, pencil boxes, pencils, file folders, paper). She will buy accessories for school uniforms and other things to increase the stock in her store.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To restock merchandise in her store

loans.name: Sura

texts.en: Sura A. is currently in the business of selling charcoal and groundnut paste (peanut butter) and is requesting a loan to stock more groundnuts to make paste to sell. Sura is 40 years old and is widowed. She has six children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a store for charcoal. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more groundnuts to make paste to sell

loans.name: Mathina

texts.en: Mathina sells groceries and kerosene at retail prices. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is 42 years old, married and has six children. Her children are doing well in school. Mathina is a Benin by tribe. She needs a loan of NGN 60,000 to purchase more kerosene and groceries to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene and groceries to sell

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en: Mabel retails sarongs, shoes, bags and jewellery. She is married with 4 children and is 47 years old. Her husband is a civil servant. Mabel hopes to own a boutique in the future. She is requesting a loan of NGN 60,000 to purchase more stock to sell. She hopes to grow her business to become bigger and stronger. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs, shoes and bags to sell

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is 41 years old, married and is blessed with 4 children. Her husband owns a business to provide the family's daily needs. They reside in Lagos. She is a trader; she sells drinks and olive oil. She started this business 10 years ago and has been successful. Through this, she can contribute to the growth and development of her children. 

She wants to improve her business so that she can buy drinks in large quantity, supply to her customers at wholesale prices and increase her profit.
She is asking for a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell.

loans.name: Lc And H Saving Club Group

texts.en:
Helena A. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called LC and H Saving Club. (In the photo that accompanies this profile, Helena is the one holding the sign.) She is 43 years old, single, and has five children who range from 18 to 23 years old. Helena was able to attend school through high school.

For 25 years, Helena has been selling medicine at the Red Light Market, which is the largest market in Liberia. She says that she provides her customers with good quality medicine and treats her customers with care, which keeps them coming to her for business. 

Helena plans to use her 7,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 35,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more medicine.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To purchase more medicine.

loans.name: Jose Wilder

texts.es:
El señor Jose Wilder S. Rodríguez  tiene 44 años y está casado hace 22 años con la señora Senaida Gongora de S. y tienen tres hijos 2 mujeres y un hombre la mayor tiene 20 años la que le sigue 18 años y el menor tiene 15 años, viven en su casa propia que con esfuerzo han conseguido tras años de ahorrar.
 
El señor Jose Wilder se dedica al servicio de taxi trabajando de chofer desde hace 4 años la señora le ayuda a su esposo trabajando como bibliotecaria en un colegio ambos trabajan para construir su casa de material de construcción mejor que con el que cuentan actualmente ya que está construida de adobe y así poder mejorar su calidad de vida. Ellos requieren el dinero para terminar de construir su casa y así poder mejorar su calidad de vida y poder darle una mejor casa donde vivir a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Jose Wilder S. Rodríguez, 44, has been married to Senaida Góngora de S. for 22 years. They have three children, two girls and a boy. The oldest is 20, the next is 18, and the youngest is 15. They live in their own house, which he got through great effort and years of saving. Jose Wilder has worked as a taxi driver for four years. His wife helps him by working as a librarian in a school. They both work to build their house from better construction material. It is currently built from adobe. This way they would be able to improve their quality of life. They need the money to finish building their house and improve their quality of life. They will then be able to give their children a better place to live.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction material for his house

loans.name: Romy Denisse

texts.es:
La Señorita Romy  Denisse es soltera y vive en la casa de sus Papas y en compañia de ellos, tiene su movilidad que hace trabajar con un chofer todos los días en el servicio de transporte urbano, ella esta a cargo de los gastos de su familia ya que sus padres ya no trabajan, y ella mantiene el hogar, ella estudia tambien, tiene a su cargo la administracion de los ingresos y que genera, como es todavia soltera y aun no tiene hijos su deseo es terminar de estudiar y poder formar su familia y ofrecerle lo mejor, ella es una persona responsable. el crédito lo esta destinando a reparaciones de la movilidad para poder seguir trabajando con la misma y tambien desea comprar pronto otra movilidad.
Esta muy agradecida con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
Romy Denisse is single and lives with her parents. She has a vehicle that a driver uses daily to provide urban public transportation. She is the household’s sole provider because her parents no longer work. Besides supporting the household, she is also studying. She manages the income. Since she is still single and has no children yet, she wants to finish her schooling so that she can form her own family and offer them the very best; she is a responsible person. The funds will be used for vehicle maintenance and repairs so that it can continue in operation; she also wants to buy a second vehicle soon. She is very grateful to Emprender and to Kiva for the trust placed in her by granting the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For vehicle maintenance.

loans.name: Bernadette Epiphanie

texts.fr: D. M. Bernadette Epiphanie est née le 06 Janvier 1964 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à TODJO Edouard, un peintre auto, Bernadette Epiphanie est mère de cinq enfants, tous scolarisés. Bernadette Epiphanie s'est installée depuis 27 ans au quartier Djassin, dans le troisième arrondissement de la ville de Porto-Novo. Elle y réside avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les différentes charges familiales. Bernadette Epiphanie n'a jamais été à l'école. Pour assurer ses différentes charges, Bernadette Epiphanie a commencé depuis 20 ans, la vente de produits cosmétiques dans son quartier. Parallèlement à cette activité, Bernadette Epiphanie vend des habits et des sous-vêtements. C'est à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, mais aussi au marché de Ouando à Porto-Novo, que Bernadette Epiphanie s'approvisionne. C'est la première fois que Bernadette Epiphanie sollicite un prêt à ALIDé, prêt qui lui servira à augmenter son fonds de roulement et à élever le niveau de son activité.
texts.en:
Bernadette Epiphanie D. M. was born on January 6, 1964 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Benin. She is married to Edouard Todjo, a car painter. She is the mother of five children, all in school. She settled in the neighborhood of Djassin, in the third “arrondissement” [communal district] of the town of Porto-Novo, 27 years ago. She lives there with her children and her husband. Together the couple provides for the different family’s expenses. Bernadette Epiphanie has never attended school. To cover her various expenses, 20 years ago she started selling cosmetics in her neighborhood. In parallel to this activity, she sells clothing and underwear. She gets her supplies from Cotonou, economic capital of Benin, but also at the Ouando market in Porto-Novo. This is the first time Bernadette Epiphanie is requesting a loan from ALIDé. This loan will allow her to increase her working capital and raise the level of her activity.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cosmetics, clothing and underwear

loans.name: Serious Women Group

texts.en:
Gorbu V. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called Serious Women. She is 39 years old, married, and has four children who range from 7 to 20 years old. She did not have the opportunity to go school.

For 5 years, Gorbu has been selling palm oil at the Kingsville #7 community Market in Margibi County, Liberia. She sells good quality palm oil, which keeps customers returning. Gorbu plans to use her 10,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 50,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy additional palm oil. Her goal is to send her children to school, build a house for her family and give them medical attention when needed.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Gorbu is the one holding the sign. Korpo W. is inset at lower right.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy additional palm oil.

loans.name: Tusa Kimu Women's Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
Nulu S. is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is a 50-year-old married mother of seven children aged 32 to 15 years, and also takes care of two orphans.

Nulu has been a poultry farmer in Buloba for twenty-four years, making sufficient profits to help support her family and pay school fees for her children. Her trustworthiness has won her many customers who buy both broilers and eggs from her home.

Nulu would like to expand her farm to enable her to continue paying school fees for her children and is therefore requesting a loan to buy more feed and chicks for her business expansion. A very hardworking and friendly lady is what best describes Nulu.

loans.use: To buy more chickens and feed for business expansion

loans.name: K. Marie

texts.fr: G. K. Marie est née en 1973 à Djigbé, dans le département de l'Ouémé au Bénin. Marie vit depuis une dizaine d'année à Hozin, non loin de Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Mariée à ZOUNMENOU Paul, un chauffeur, Marie est mère de cinq enfants, dont certains sont scolarisés. Seulement deux des enfants restent encore à la charge du couple. La famille vit ensemble et le couple assure les différentes charges familiales. Marie n'a jamais fréquenté l'école. Il y a près de 8 ans que Marie prépare et vend de l'alcool local (communément appelé "Sodabi") à son domicile. Marie s'approvisionne en vin de palme et en sucre à Cotonou, en vue de la préparation de la boisson. Marie a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. Marie sollicite un troisième prêt pour renforcer son activité et préparer plus de boissons, afin de se faire plus de profits.
texts.en:
Marie K G. was born in 1973 in Djigbé, in the Ouémé region of Bénin. Marie has lived for twelve years in Hozin, not far from Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin. Married to Paul Zounmenou, a chauffeur, Marie is the mother of five children, some of whom went to school. Only two of the children still live under their parents' care. The family lives together and the couple provides for the family's different needs. Marie never attended school. Almost eight years ago, Marie began preparing and selling the local alcoholic beverage (commonly called "Sodabi") from her home. Marie stocks up on palm wine and sugar in Cotonou, in preparation for making the drink. Marie has already benefited from two loans from ALIDé, loans which she repaid in full. Marie is asking for a third loan to strengthen her business by making more drinks and thus seeing a higher profit.

Translated from French by Kelly Percival, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of palm wine and sugar to make "Sodabi"

loans.name: Silvia

texts.es:
La Señora Silvia es soltera, se dedica a la venta de abarrotes desde hace cinco años, ella vive sola en el barrio Cupesi ya que ahi se encuentra  su tienda donde vende  todos los productos de primera necesidad es una tienda muy surtida ya que tiene lo necesario pero ella necesita ampliar su negocio y con el dinero del credito la Sra. Silvia comprara mas mercaderia para asi tener mejores ingresos y  llegar al objetivo que se propuso.
